class="Form-newsletter-text-wrapper"> <div class="Form-newsletter-title"> Green Room Newsletter </div> <div class="Form-newsletter-submissionSuccess"> <p><b>You’re subscribed!</b></p><p></p><p>Please check your inbox for your confirmation.</p> </div> <div class="Form-newsletter-description">Stay ahead of what’s hitting Chicago stages, galleries, museums and more with Green Room, WBEZ’s weekly arts & culture newsletter!</div> <div class="Form-newsletter-errorMessage"><p>Sorry, there was an error registering your email.</p></div> </div> <form data-ajax-endpoint="https://sfmc-subscribe.wbez.org/v1/subscription" class="Form-newsletter-form" method="POST" > <div class="Form-newsletter-item"> <div class="EmailInput"><label class="EmailInput-label"><span>Email</span> <input class="EmailInput-input" type="email" name="email" placeholder="name@email.com" required aria-required="true"> </label> </div> <button class="Button" type="submit">Sign Up </button> </div> <div class="Form-items-item"> <input type="hidden" name="acquisition_campaign" value="ARTS_Affordance"> </div> <div class="Form-newsletter-disclaimer"> <p>By subscribing, you agree with WBEZ’s <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/terms-of-use" target="_blank" >Terms of Use</a> and <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/privacy-policy" target="_blank" >Privacy Policy</a></p> </div> </form> </bsp-form> </div> </div><p>Bonds died of a heart attack in 1972, shortly after turning 59. She was buried in south suburban Glenwood alongside her mother — also an influential music teacher on the South Side, where Bonds grew up and spent her early career. Despite her stature in American music history, however, Bonds’ own grave is unmarked.</p><p>That will soon change. This weekend, Northwestern University — Bonds’ alma mater — hosts a ceremony and performance dedicating a new headstone. A rendering of the marker will be shown to the public, then installed later this year.</p><p>Malcolm J. Merriweather, a specialist in Bonds’ music who leads the New York Philharmonic Chorus, says it came to his attention that the late composer did not have a headstone during a conversation with her great-niece last year. Along with Bonds’ descendant, Merriweather used his personal funds to pay for the headstone outright, which included proceeds from his own arrangements of Bonds’ music.</p><p>“I think a characteristic of Black life is making sure those who have gone before us are taken care of,” Merriweather said. “We both decided that we were going to make it happen for this incredible composer, educator, pianist and performer that has inspired so many of us in our careers.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-c20000" name="image-c20000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1278ad0/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F37%2F6f%2Fcb35e4cb4f6892cdff9f6e530ba9%2Fbondsmusic-2602270177.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/2344214/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F37%2F6f%2Fcb35e4cb4f6892cdff9f6e530ba9%2Fbondsmusic-2602270177.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/df205c8/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F37%2F6f%2Fcb35e4cb4f6892cdff9f6e530ba9%2Fbondsmusic-2602270177.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Sidney Jackson Jr., President and CEO of Chicago Sinfonietta poses for a portrait along the Chicago River in downtown Chicago on February 26, 2026. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/df205c8/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F37%2F6f%2Fcb35e4cb4f6892cdff9f6e530ba9%2Fbondsmusic-2602270177.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/2d04959/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F37%2F6f%2Fcb35e4cb4f6892cdff9f6e530ba9%2Fbondsmusic-2602270177.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/df205c8/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F37%2F6f%2Fcb35e4cb4f6892cdff9f6e530ba9%2Fbondsmusic-2602270177.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>“It’s always been Sinfonietta’s mission to champion composers and artists of color as well as women. To honor Margaret Bonds’ legacy with this project was a natural fit,” said Sidney Jackson Jr., president and CEO of Chicago Sinfonietta.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Manuel Martinez/Manuel Martinez/WBEZ</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Merriweather then teamed up with Sidney Jackson, CEO of the Chicago Sinfonietta, to amplify the effort and organize a dedication ceremony. The Sinfonietta has championed Bonds’ music, most recently her “Montgomery Variations,” composed after the assassination of Martin Luther King, Jr. According to Jackson, many musicians participating in this weekend’s concert are donating their time for the cause.</p><p>“It's always been Sinfonietta’s mission to champion composers and artists of color as well as women. To honor Margaret Bonds’ legacy with this project was a natural fit,” Jackson said.</p><p>The effort recalls a similar one to <a class="Link" href="https://weta.org/fm/classical-score/weta-classical-listener-installs-grave-marker-florence-price" target="_blank" ><u>install a marker</u></a> on the grave of composer <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/curious-city/2022/07/21/who-was-florence-price" target="_blank" ><u>Florence Price</u></a>, who provided essential mentorship to Bonds as a fellow Black female composer living on Chicago’s South Side. Price is also buried in the south Chicago suburbs, at Lincoln Cemetery in Blue Island.</p><p>Bonds studied at Chicago Musical College before enrolling at Northwestern University at just 16. After getting a bachelor’s and master’s at Northwestern, she pursued further study at The Juilliard School in New York City. She lived and worked there as well as Los Angeles, where she died.</p><p>Bonds’ years at Northwestern were unhappy ones. She was not permitted to live or practice piano on campus, like her white peers. She sought refuge at the Evanston Public Library, whose basement bookshelves became something of an escape. There, she stumbled upon Langston Hughes’ “The Negro Speaks of Rivers” for the first time.</p><p>“I was in this prejudiced university, this terribly prejudiced place,” she reflected later, “and I know that poem helped save me.”</p><p>Hughes would become her most important collaborator and a dear friend. She frequently set his writing to music, including “The Ballad of the Brown King,” which CBS featured in a 1960 Christmas broadcast.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" data-embed> <iframe width="200" height="150" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/kQE-S3b4FA0?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen title="The Ballad of the Brown King: I. Of the Three Wise Men"></iframe> </div> </div></div><p>Generations later, in 2003, pianist Toni-Marie Montgomery became the first Black person and the first woman to lead Northwestern’s Bienen School of Music — the same institution Bonds passed through decades earlier. Before she retired in 2023, Montgomery kept a picture of Bonds in her office.</p><p>“When I think of anyone who looks like me going to a historically white institution in the 1930s, I just think it's amazing,” she said.</p><p><i>Friday’s dedication concert at Northwestern’s Pick-Staiger Concert Hall will feature Chicago Sinfonietta musicians, as well as guest singers. The Kenwood United Church of Christ will host a panel with Bonds performers and researchers the following day. Both are free and open to the public. RSVPs and more information are available at </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicagosinfonietta.org/especially-do-i-believe/" target="_blank" ><i><u>chicagosinfonietta.org</u></i></a><i>.</i></p>
entries.author: Hannah Edgar | WBEZ

entries.title: Pro-Israel group's interest in Chicago-area Democratic congressional fights puts candidates on the defensive
entries.summary: <p>When the American Israel Public Affairs Committee reached out to Democratic congressional candidate Jeff Cohen in November, he was open to talking about the group’s potential support in his run for retiring U.S. Rep. Jan Schakowsky’s seat.</p><p>Cohen, an economist from Evanston, says he staunchly supports the U.S.-Israel alliance and was interested in hearing from the group that has championed that cause for decades. At the same time, he does not believe U.S. military aid to Israel should be a blank check.</p><p>The meeting was at a coffee shop and lasted an hour. Cohen says he expressed support for Israel but “probably sounded like someone who was going to take a very hard look” at the country’s “behavior” in Gaza.</p><p>Cohen never heard back from AIPAC. Then he noticed a deluge of donations from around the country for another candidate — a state senator who had not called for stricter conditions on aid to Israel.</p><p>Cohen is among several Democrats in four wide-open Chicago-area congressional primaries to have met with AIPAC and learned the group has drawn a hard line on one thing: unconditional U.S. military aid to Israel. The topic has become a flashpoint for candidates and voters as more Democrats call for improving human rights in Gaza.</p><p>AIPAC donors and affiliates have spent more than $10.6 million on the group’s preferred candidates in the four races, a WBEZ analysis of federal campaign disclosures found. Those candidates, meantime, have evaded most questions, or favored Israel, in a WBEZ survey about U.S. support for Israel and the war in Gaza.</p><p>WBEZ surveyed the 46 candidates in the Chicago area’s four hard-fought Democratic congressional primaries about whether there should be strict U.S. conditions on military aid to Israel, whether that country has committed genocide in Gaza, and whether AIPAC funding should be off-limits in these races.</p><p>Most of the respondents said yes to those questions, but the four AIPAC-aligned candidates would not answer yes or no.<b> </b></p><p>Big campaign spending isn’t new for AIPAC, which has been around for 72 years. But the group is operating more covertly than ever, Democratic strategists say. AIPAC is working through newly formed political action committees that are hard to trace and that bankroll campaign mailers, phone calls and TV commercials. So far, that publicity hasn’t mentioned the Middle East, focusing instead on things like immigration and affordability.</p><p>AIPAC has not responded to WBEZ questions about its candidate selection criteria or Chicago-area tactics.</p><p>“They’re trying to influence these elections … by invoking other issues that have nothing to do with Israel,” says veteran political consultant David Axelrod, who was chief strategist and senior advisor to President Barack Obama.</p><p>“This isn’t unusual in American politics,” he adds. “But given the volatility of issues involving Israel now, it’s conspicuous in this case that they’re working so hard to submerge their own participation.”</p><h3>Secretive spending</h3><p>The AIPAC-linked candidates — all Democrats — include Cook County Commissioner Donna Miller in the 2nd District, Chicago City Treasurer Melissa Conyears-Ervin in the 7th, former U.S. Rep. Melissa Bean in the 8th and state Sen. Laura Fine in the 9th.</p><p>AIPAC is supporting them in two main ways. The first is steering AIPAC donors to the candidates through online fundraisers, in-person events and email solicitations.</p><p>In all, 1,726 donors to AIPAC or its main super PAC had contributed to at least one of the four candidates by the start of the year, according to the WBEZ analysis. Of those donors, 1,524 (88.3%) lived outside Illinois and nearly a third contributed to more than one of the candidates. The AIPAC-linked donations totaled nearly $2.9 million.</p><p>Candidates receiving those donations have depicted the link to AIPAC as a coincidence.</p><p>The second way AIPAC has propelled the Chicago-area candidates is through super PACs, which cannot donate directly to candidates or coordinate with them but can raise and spend unlimited sums on their behalf.</p><p>AIPAC-tied super PACs have spent more than $7.7 million on TV ads, phone outreach and mailers for the four candidates, according to federal filings.</p><p>AIPAC, a national lobbying organization with more than 6 million members, tries to ensure U.S. policies and public perception favor Israel. The group spends big on Republican and Democratic candidates alike and aggressively targets Israel critics.</p><p>But AIPAC over the years has fallen out of favor with some Democrats and Jewish progressives who have recoiled from Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s tactics in Gaza and from AIPAC’s backing of Republicans who <a class="Link" href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2022/mar/23/aipac-pro-israel-group-backs-insurrectionist-republicans" target="_blank" ><u>voted to overturn</u></a> the 2020 presidential election.</p><p>Illinois’ two-term Democratic governor, JB Pritzker, believes AIPAC has “abandoned their principles.” Pritzker, the state’s third Jewish governor, was a driving force behind construction of the Illinois Holocaust Museum.</p><p>“Just because they donate to certain Democrats doesn’t change the fact that they are heeding the words and direction of Jared Kushner and other Trump acolytes,” Pritzker campaign spokesman Alex Gough said in a statement.</p><p>Pritzker is not alone with that sentiment.</p><p>“There’s no question they’re right-wing,” says Steve Sheffey, who writes the Jewish newsletter The Fine Print and was an AIPAC member for 25 years. “They wouldn’t think of themselves as that, but they are right-wing on the issue that they advocate for, and also right-wing in who they support.”</p><p>Axelrod says that reputation has pushed AIPAC to operate “under the cloak of darkness.”</p><p>“Younger Jews who aren’t as steeped in [Israeli] history may have been horrified by what happened on Oct. 7 but then were horrified by what followed,” Axelrod says.</p><p>Hamas killed more than 1,200 people during its Oct. 7, 2023, attack in Israel, according to Israeli officials. More than 72,000 Palestinians have been killed since, according to Gaza health officials. Some died during a food shortage that a U.N. panel declared was a famine. A slew of human rights groups have concluded Israel has committed genocide in Gaza — a finding that Israel denies.</p><p>AIPAC has shown interest in Chicago-area Democratic congressional primaries that seem to be wide open after the retirement of longtime incumbents.</p><p>“With these four districts, where it can be anybody’s game, they’re heavily invested,” says Nick Sous, an organizer with the U.S. Palestinian Community Network, which is critical of AIPAC.</p><p>AIPAC has a chance in three of the races to replace incumbents increasingly critical of weapons sales to Israel.</p><p>Rep. Robin Kelly, who is stepping down to run for retiring U.S. Sen. Dick Durbin’s seat, and retiring Reps. Danny Davis and Schakowsky signed onto the “Block the Bombs” bill last year. The measure would place more stringent human rights conditions on the sale of certain weapons — like bunker-busting bombs that can tear through concrete.</p><p>“They’re trying to force a power shift,” says Sous, whose group has pushed Illinois politicians to sign onto the bill.</p><h3>Shell PACs</h3><p>Newly formed super PACs with ties to AIPAC cropped up in January, joining the United Democracy Project, which has been active for four years and is throwing its weight behind Conyears-Ervin in the race for the 7th District, which stretches from the western suburbs to some Downtown and South Side areas.</p><p>The websites of <a class="Link" href="https://affordablechicagonow.org/" target="_blank" ><u>Affordable Chicago Now</u></a> and <a class="Link" href="https://electchicagowomen.org/" target="_blank" ><u>Elect Chicago Women</u></a> include no information about Bean, Fine or Miller and no mention of Israel.</p><p>The committees’ ties to AIPAC and UDP aren’t obvious. But a WBEZ review of federal and state disclosures found the groups identifying shared registered agents and vendors</p><p>Their TV commercials and mailers have contained no reference to Israel. They have focused on domestic issues such as health care and immigration enforcement.</p><p>Neither ACN nor ECW responded to WBEZ questions on why the groups have poured millions of dollars into Fine, Miller and Beans’ candidacies.</p><p>In the 2nd Congressional District, which covers part of the South Side and some nearby suburbs and rural areas, Miller is among 11 Democratic candidates vying to replace Kelly.</p><p>In addition to nearly $1.5 million in super PAC spending, Miller has received a huge amount directly from AIPAC donors. They accounted for more than 72% of her $1.3 million in total receipts at the start of the year, according to the WBEZ analysis.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-100000" name="html-embed-module-100000"></a><div class="flourish-embed flourish-chart" data-src="visualisation/27812440"><script src="https://public.flourish.studio/resources/embed.js"></script><noscript><img src="https://public.flourish.studio/visualisation/27812440/thumbnail" width="100%" alt="visualization" /></noscript></div> </div> </div><p>At least 578, or 65%, of her individual donors had contributed to AIPAC or UDP, the analysis shows. Of those, 515 (89%) lived outside Illinois. Since 2021, those donors and their immediate family members had given more than $28.5 million to the two PACs.</p><p>Still, Miller leans into a technical truth: “AIPAC has not given me any campaign contributions,” she told WBEZ.</p><p>At a forum this month, Miller said she had received funds from a “broad base.”</p><p>“I don’t think that money coming into your campaign decides how you’re going to legislate, how you’re going to effectuate change in your district,” Miller said.</p><p>Miller’s campaign this week circulated a letter from Jewish leaders, including U.S. Rep. Brad Schneider and Chicago Ald. Debra Silverstein, that paints AIPAC’s role in the race as “Jewish engagement” and warns that criticizing the engagement “risks reinforcing harmful narratives at a time when antisemitism is rising.”</p><p>But Miller’s AIPAC support led to her <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2026/02/19/rep-jan-schakowsky-withdrawal-donna-miller-endorsement-2nd-congressional-district-aipac-support" target="_blank" ><u>losing Schakowsky’s endorsement</u></a> this month. The longtime congresswoman, who is Jewish, said Illinois “deserves leaders who put voters first, not AIPAC.”</p><h3>Ground skirmishes</h3><p>AIPAC’s role is drawing fire from progressive candidates, especially in the 9th Congressional District, which stretches from the North Side to several northern and northwestern suburbs. The district is home to many Israelis and Palestinians, according to the U.S. Census Bureau, which doesn’t track religion.</p><p>In that primary, federal campaign finance records show, Elect Chicago Women has shelled out $1.4 million for Fine, the state senator.</p><p>Fine has also landed huge sums of AIPAC-tied cash. At least 987, or 67%, of her individual donors by the start of this year had contributed to AIPAC or UDP, the WBEZ analysis shows. Of those, 851 (86%) lived outside Illinois. The AIPAC-linked donors accounted for 73% of her $1.9 million in total receipts. Since 2021, the donors and their immediate family members have given more than $46 million to those pro-Israel committees.</p><p>This has become an issue for Fine in recent weeks. At a <a class="Link" href="https://x.com/DanielBiss/status/2024672880714301700?s=20" target="_blank" ><u>forum</u></a>, candidates were handed signs with “yes” on one side and “no” on the other and asked a series of single-answer questions. When the moderator queried the group about whether they accepted money from AIPAC or its supporters, Fine was the only candidate among six on-stage to hold up a “yes” sign.</p><p>Evanston Mayor Daniel Biss posted video of the moment on his X account and drew nearly 22,000 views.</p><p>“She supports a blank check of military aid for Israel,” said Biss, who is Jewish and frequently talks up his ties to Israel but increasingly criticizes its actions. “That is a right-wing policy that is bad for Palestinians, Jews, Israelis, America and the world.”</p><p>Fine, also Jewish, hit back, saying Biss himself took AIPAC-connected money in 2024.</p><p>Elect Chicago Women last weekend unveiled its first negative TV ad against Biss, accusing him of “saying anything to get elected.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-810000" name="html-embed-module-810000"></a><div class="flourish-embed flourish-chart" data-src="visualisation/27815367"><script src="https://public.flourish.studio/resources/embed.js"></script><noscript><img src="https://public.flourish.studio/visualisation/27815367/thumbnail" width="100%" alt="visualization" /></noscript></div> </div> </div><p>In the 8th Congressional District, which covers some western and northwestern suburbs, Bean is among candidates hoping to replace Rep. Raja Krishnamoorthi, who is running for Durbin’s Senate seat. She has benefited from $2.6 million in AIPAC-linked super PAC spending and, by the start of the year, her campaign had received more than a half-million dollars from AIPAC donors.</p><p>At least 314, or 57%, of Bean’s individual donors have also contributed to AIPAC or UDP since 2021, the WBEZ analysis shows. Of those, 272 (87%) lived outside Illinois. Those donors accounted for more than 39% of her $1.3 million in total receipts by the start of the year.</p><p>At a news conference focused on AIPAC spending, Bean rival Junaid Ahmed accused her of selling her candidacy.</p><p>“Melissa Bean will take their millions and then rubber stamp billions in unchecked military aid to Israel. Melissa Bean will look the other way as Israel commits a genocide,” said Ahmed, a director at a cloud computing firm.</p><p>In response to WBEZ’s survey, Bean declined to provide yes-or-no answers but added, “I support a two-state solution in the Middle East that allows both Israelis and Palestinians to live in peace, safety and dignity.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-f50000" name="html-embed-module-f50000"></a><div class="flourish-embed flourish-chart" data-src="visualisation/27815247"><script src="https://public.flourish.studio/resources/embed.js"></script><noscript><img src="https://public.flourish.studio/visualisation/27815247/thumbnail" width="100%" alt="visualization" /></noscript></div> </div> </div><p>AIPAC has also been accused of parachuting into majority-Black areas where, candidates say, U.S.-Israel relations are not a top concern.</p><p>“They’re not investing in our schools. They’re not supporting the marginalized," said Anthony Driver, who is running to replace Davis. “The 7th District is not for sale. My community is not for sale.”</p><p>Peters, a 2nd District candidate, stood with Driver at the AIPAC-focused news conference.</p><p>“I’m Black and Jewish and … AIPAC is not my friend,” Petershe said. “[I]t gets conflated that AIPAC is about Jewish safety. I want to dissuade that. It is about Israel. Jewish safety comes through solidarity.”</p><h3>Choosing favorites</h3><p>A whopping 46 Democrats are running across the four congressional primaries. Most respondents to the WBEZ survey showed support for Palestinian rights.</p><p>More than two-thirds of respondents answered they would denounce AIPAC funding if offered. Two-thirds said they support strict human rights conditions on aid to Israel. More than half said they believe Israel has committed genocide in Gaza.</p><p>The four AIPAC-linked candidates were among a minority of respondents who declined to provide yes-or-no answers to a majority of questions. Conyears-Ervin did answer one question with a straightforward answer, saying she would not oppose sending U.S. military aid to Israel today.</p><p>Some primary contenders say AIPAC has a litmus test for choosing whom to back: Does the candidate support unconditional U.S. aid to Israel?</p><p>A “no” answer is disqualifying, according to candidates in the 2nd, 8th and 9th districts who took meetings with either AIPAC or the United Democracy Project, the group’s super PAC.</p><p>State Rep. La Shawn Ford, D-Chicago, another candidate running to replace Davis, met with AIPAC late last year at a community graduation in his district. The AIPAC representative stressed the effect of Hamas’ Oct. 7 attack in southern Israel, telling Ford, “You have to remember that date,” the candidate recalled.</p><p>Ford’s impression was that AIPAC would support candidates only if they oppose the “Block the Bombs” bill.</p><p>The AIPAC contact, whom Ford would not identify, eventually called him with news that the group would instead support Conyears-Ervin “and that they’re going to come out hard for her,” Ford recalled.</p><p>AIPAC’s spending has been most transparent in that race, where it is supporting Conyears-Ervin to the tune of $1.5 million through the UDP, whose donors through December have been disclosed. AIPAC’s role in that district, the 7th, has also evolved. At first, its donors were showering hundreds of thousands of dollars on River North developer Jason Friedman.</p><p>In a message to WBEZ, Conyears-Ervin responded to accusations that AIPAC’s support would influence her voting in Congress: “The idea that a Black woman’s vote is for sale is insulting and racist.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-900000" name="html-embed-module-900000"></a><div class="flourish-embed flourish-chart" data-src="visualisation/27813578"><script src="https://public.flourish.studio/resources/embed.js"></script><noscript><img src="https://public.flourish.studio/visualisation/27813578/thumbnail" width="100%" alt="visualization" /></noscript></div> </div> </div><p>State Sen. Willie Preston, D-Chicago, running to replace Kelly in the 2nd, also spoke with AIPAC but says it seemed the group sought “100% control.”</p><p>“The problem with AIPAC is that they are looking for slaves,” says Preston, chair of the Illinois Senate Black Caucus.</p><p>Neither AIPAC nor UDP responded to requests for comment about the alleged litmus test, but UDP spokesperson Patrick Dorton described it to the Jewish Telegraph this month.</p><p>“We are going to have a focus on stopping candidates who are detractors of Israel or who want to put conditions on aid,” Dorton said.</p>
entries.author: Mawa Iqbal | WBEZ

entries.title: Double Door co-owners close the door on plan to revive music venue in Uptown
entries.summary: <p>With renovation estimates spiking more than 200% and a pattern of changing behaviors among concertgoers, Double Door co-owner Sean Mulroney was left with little choice but to close the door on the music club’s anticipated revival at Uptown’s Wilson Theatre.</p><p>“The price tag just didn’t make sense,” Mulroney shared with the Sun-Times after his Feb. 23 announcement that the project — in the works since late 2018 — would not be moving forward.</p><p>“Our original cost estimates were $2-$3 million, but post-COVID, with the increase in everything and the fact that it's a historic building, costs moved up into the $9 million range,” Mulroney said of the skyrocketing figures for the significant renovations that were necessary to ready the space, which had been a vaudeville theater and bank during its 117-year history.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-480000" name="image-480000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/232cac4/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+156/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F8f%2Fde%2F24f87b70463ab58214c7a754413c%2Fmulroney-031222-28.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/3896bc6/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+156/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F8f%2Fde%2F24f87b70463ab58214c7a754413c%2Fmulroney-031222-28.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/788df01/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+156/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F8f%2Fde%2F24f87b70463ab58214c7a754413c%2Fmulroney-031222-28.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="The exterior of the old bank building at 1050 West Wilson Avenue, where the new Double Door will be located at, in the Uptown neighborhood, Friday, March 11, 2022. Sean Mulroney, the owner of Double Door hopes to open the new venue sometime in fall. | Tyler Pasciak LaRiviere/Sun-Times" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/788df01/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+156/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F8f%2Fde%2F24f87b70463ab58214c7a754413c%2Fmulroney-031222-28.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e35d5f8/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+156/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F8f%2Fde%2F24f87b70463ab58214c7a754413c%2Fmulroney-031222-28.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/788df01/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+156/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F8f%2Fde%2F24f87b70463ab58214c7a754413c%2Fmulroney-031222-28.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>The exterior of the former Wilson Teater at 1050 W. Wilson Ave., where the new Double Door was supposed to relocate. </p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Tyler Pasciak LaRiviere/Sun-Times file</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>So far, about $1.5 million has been invested into the project, including the cost of the building.</p><p>It’s the latest hurdle for the beloved venue, first established in Wicker Park in 1994, that was a go-to for homegrown acts like Liz Phair, Veruca Salt and The Smashing Pumpkins and has been once again trying to find its footing in Chicago’s music scene for nearly a decade since being booted from its original location on Milwaukee Avenue in 2017 following a series of disagreements over the lease.</p><p>By 2024, things seemed hopeful as Mulroney and partner Peter Bruce (who owns the building) had raised about $1 million in capital from private investors and were successful in securing an additional <a class="Link" href="https://www.chicago.gov/city/en/depts/mayor/press_room/press_releases/2024/june/community-development-grants-2024.html" target="_blank" ><u>$5 million community development grant</u></a> from the city of Chicago. With the progress, the team hosted a few small-scale concerts and opened the doors to public tours during the Chicago Architecture’s Open House weekend that year.</p><p>But there were challenges in closing the gap on the additional funding needed. Because Double Door had not been active for years, with no recent tax records or revenue, it was considered a new business, which can be viewed as high-risk to some lenders.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-d50000" name="image-d50000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f008622/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+158/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F1c%2F36%2F56bedee34673a82a0205d2e831c3%2Fmulroney-031222-2.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/11c826d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+158/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F1c%2F36%2F56bedee34673a82a0205d2e831c3%2Fmulroney-031222-2.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/402a961/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+158/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F1c%2F36%2F56bedee34673a82a0205d2e831c3%2Fmulroney-031222-2.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Sean Mulroney, owner of Double Door sits inside the location of the new double door which is inside an old bank building at 1050 West Wilson Avenue, in the Uptown neighborhood, Friday, March 11, 2022. Mulroney hopes to have the new Double Door open some time this fall. | Tyler Pasciak LaRiviere/Sun-Times" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/402a961/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+158/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F1c%2F36%2F56bedee34673a82a0205d2e831c3%2Fmulroney-031222-2.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/0deee0b/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+158/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F1c%2F36%2F56bedee34673a82a0205d2e831c3%2Fmulroney-031222-2.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/402a961/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+158/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F1c%2F36%2F56bedee34673a82a0205d2e831c3%2Fmulroney-031222-2.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>“It’s a shame because it’s a stunning facility,” said Double Door co-owner Sean Mulroney of the space that was to have been the new home of the music venue. “While the inside would have been spectacular, the size would only have been a little bit bigger than the [original] Double Door in terms of capacity, except the cost was exponentially more.”</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Tyler Pasciak LaRiviere/Sun-Times file</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Mulroney went to nine banks with the same pitch and received the same response. “It came down to the amount of funds I'd have to basically guarantee either through equity, sale of parts of the business or loans, and it wasn't in the stars for me,” said Mulroney. Access to the $5 million grant eventually expired, and the team worked “down to the wire” to try to find alternatives.</p><p>“It's a shame because it’s a stunning facility. But the thing is, with these old theaters, they're really, really expensive to redo,” he said. “While the inside would have been spectacular, the size would only have been a little bit bigger than the [original] Double Door in terms of capacity, except the cost was exponentially more.”</p><p>That meant he’d be looking to book programming on at least five and up to seven nights a week to even try to break even, but it wasn’t a sustainable plan. “There’s competition — less people are touring and less people are buying tickets,” Mulroney said. “And given the climate we are in economically and the change in behavior of young folks who can’t afford to always go out and are drinking less, the amount to redo a historic building for that purpose was not feasible financially.”</p><p>The Double Door setback comes at the same time that another historic venue revival is gaining traction. On Feb. 21, Ald. Daniel La Spata (1st), posted a<a class="Link" href="https://www.facebook.com/watch/?v=2698590633837486" target="_blank" ><u>video on social media</u></a> previewing “a new era” for the Congress Theater, which has been closed since 2013. It comes after developers secured a<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/city-hall/2026/01/14/landmark-congress-theater-federal-loan-preservation-finance-committee-city-council" target="_blank" ><u>$25 million federal loan</u></a> backed by city funds. Unlike the indie Double Door, though, the Congress has considerable corporate backing as it is operated by AEG.</p><p>“I wish the city would look at us and go, you’re bringing 62 jobs and $8 million in revenue to this community every year, maybe we can give you a hand a little more than the $5 million,” he countered. “But at some point, the little guys can't afford it and I'm a little guy.”</p><p>The same lack of access to funding amid inflated costs has been affecting bottom lines for a number of independent entertainment venues across the city; as Sun-Times <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/music/2026/02/03/chicago-indie-venues-health-metro-ramova-salt-shed" target="_blank" ><u>recently reported</u></a>, only one in four is currently profitable.</p><p>Even so, Mulroney has not given up hope. He still plans to bring Double Door back to life in a new spot in the near future, given a different venue and financial scenario. “I still am looking for another home for the Double Door, and there are some very good possibilities,” he said, noting he’s zeroing in on the Logan Square and Avondale neighborhoods.</p><p>In the meantime, Mulroney has partnered with Gallery Cabaret, the long-running bar and performance space in Bucktown, helping to revive it after current owner Mike Strandberg briefly closed shop the past two months to re-evaluate operations. There’s a soft opening planned for March 1, with events planned through April. “I'm going to start putting some of my people in there and some bands. I’ve got all of these ideas I want to try out,” said Mulroney, aiming to hold true to Double Door’s original formula.</p><p>The venue was known for its eclectic lineups, and what set it apart was how it treated every band like a headliner on a national tour, Mulroney said.</p><p>“'If the talent loves it, that comes across to the audience. And there's no better feeling in the world than walking in the room with a band that's on stage and realizing that all those people are having as good a time as I was.”</p>
entries.author: Selena Fragassi

entries.title: ICE protesters keep beating Trump in Chicago court, but the battles take a toll. 'It’s about intimidation'
entries.summary: <p>Photographs of Ray Collins and Jocelyne Robledo in federal custody are just a Google search away, as easy to find as the social media posts calling them<b> </b>“armed rioters” and “deranged individuals."</p><p>Authorities arrested the Englewood couple five months ago outside of an immigration processing center<b> </b>in Broadview, just weeks after President Donald Trump launched a pummeling deportation campaign across the Chicago area last September.</p><p>Their assault cases quickly fell apart when a <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2025/10/08/feds-dropping-charges-against-couple-who-lawfully-carried-guns-outside-ice-facility" target="_blank" >grand jury refused to indict</a>. Collins still found himself being called “everything from a thug to a predator.” And he now has a warning for potential employers who might try to look him up: “I was arrested for a felony.”</p><p>“It’s almost embarrassing,” he told the Chicago Sun-Times.</p><p>But he’s resilient.</p><p>“I know myself and my character, that those things would never stick,” Collins said. “They can’t tarnish what I’ve done in my community. They can’t tarnish who I am as a person.”</p><p>Collins and Robledo are among a growing number of protesters who have been left to pick up the pieces after taking on the Trump administration in court — and winning.</p><p>Prosecutions for nonimmigration crimes tied to Operation Midway Blitz have disintegrated at an alarming rate at the Dirksen Federal Courthouse since October. Cases against 17<b> </b>of 32 known defendants <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2026/tracker-federal-prosecutions-chicago-status-trumps-immigration-blitz-ice" target="_blank" >have already collapsed</a>, including the ones against Collins and Robledo.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-420000" name="image-420000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/02dbc82/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fde%2Ff3%2F78dc2ce04265a3e22c5276e8b7f7%2Fbroadview-092825-0096.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/766a1e5/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fde%2Ff3%2F78dc2ce04265a3e22c5276e8b7f7%2Fbroadview-092825-0096.JPG 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8eb54c5/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fde%2Ff3%2F78dc2ce04265a3e22c5276e8b7f7%2Fbroadview-092825-0096.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="BROADVIEW-092825-0096.JPG" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8eb54c5/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fde%2Ff3%2F78dc2ce04265a3e22c5276e8b7f7%2Fbroadview-092825-0096.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8d2e831/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fde%2Ff3%2F78dc2ce04265a3e22c5276e8b7f7%2Fbroadview-092825-0096.JPG 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8eb54c5/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fde%2Ff3%2F78dc2ce04265a3e22c5276e8b7f7%2Fbroadview-092825-0096.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Agents with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement and U.S. Customs and Border Protection man the gate at the Broadview processing facility on Sept. 27, 2025, the day Ray Collins and Jocelyne Robledo were arrested.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Candace Dane Chambers/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>But they still come at a cost. A federal prosecution is intimidating. It carries the threat of prison time. Damaging news stories spread online. Freedoms are often restricted, even in minor cases. Lawyers are needed, though federal defenders have saved people from big legal bills.</p><p>Then there’s jail.</p><p>The 17 cleared defendants spent a combined 150 days in federal custody, records show. That doesn’t include 35 days, and counting, that Juan Espinoza Martinez has been held by immigration authorities <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2026/01/22/federal-jury-rejects-bovino-murder-plot-after-called-upon-stand-up-overreaching-government" target="_blank" >since he was acquitted</a> for allegedly placing a hit on Gregory Bovino, the Border Patrol official who became the face of the deportation operation.</p><p>That’s to say nothing of the flesh-and-blood cost borne by Marimar Martinez, the woman <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2026/02/03/marimar-martinez-shot-border-patrol-chicago-speaks-out-after-good-pretti-deaths-i-am-their-voice" target="_blank" >shot five times by a Border Patrol agent</a> on the Southwest Side in early October.</p><p>The stakes aren’t so high in every case. Jackie Guataquira, whose four-month old misdemeanor case was recently dropped, said she never spent a night in jail and didn’t have to physically appear in court. But the prosecution kept her from visiting family in Mexico, Guataquira said.</p><p>It just shows “they want to come for people at every single level,” she told the Sun-Times.</p><p>“They’re really just trying to take people’s lives away, deport them out of this country, or at the … more minor level, paint people who are righteously protesting and standing up to this as ‘terrorists,’” she said. “They’re slapping these people’s photos all over social media for this, just to get people away from being able to protest.”</p><h3>‘Your life gets turned upside down’</h3><p>Federal prosecutors are expected to bring charges only when they can prove them to a jury beyond a reasonable doubt. Normally, they boast <a class="Link" href="https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2023/06/14/fewer-than-1-of-defendants-in-federal-criminal-cases-were-acquitted-in-2022/#:~:text=This%20analysis%20is%20based%20on,Office%20of%20the%20U.S.%20Courts" target="_blank" >a conviction rate of around 90%</a>. But Trump’s Justice Department has suffered a string of high-profile losses tied to its national immigration campaign, including in a recent <a class="Link" href="https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2026-02-06/federal-public-defenders-winning" target="_blank" >six-case losing streak</a> in Los Angeles.</p><p>In Chicago, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2025/05/30/andrew-boutros-interim-us-attorney-chicago-judges-role-pam-bondi" target="_blank" >U.S. Attorney Andrew Boutros’</a> office is looking at a best-case conviction rate of around 47% in such cases. That’s assuming it secures a conviction against each of the remaining 15 defendants, and no additional charges are brought.</p><p>Boutros said many of the cases were brought as a result of “reactive arrests” in the field. Some of them were better suited for state court, he said. Others were dropped out of concern that jurors would reject charges even when they’re proven, or for mitigating factors like mental health.</p><p>“Our grace should not be confused as a reflection of the strength of any particular case or whether a charge should have been filed,” Boutros said in a statement. “It is a testament to our view that the role of the prosecutor is to seek justice and not just convict.</p><p>“We decide cases based on facts, law, and equities without regard to the attitude of sneering disbelief held by a certain group of critics.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-6e0000" name="html-embed-module-6e0000"></a><div class="flourish-embed flourish-table" data-src="visualisation/27349648"><script src="https://public.flourish.studio/resources/embed.js"></script><noscript><img src="https://public.flourish.studio/visualisation/27349648/thumbnail" width="100%" alt="table visualization" /></noscript></div> </div> </div><p>Attorney General Pam Bondi <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2025/03/28/former-prosecutor-andrew-boutros-named-chicagos-interim-u-s-attorney" target="_blank" >initially appointed Boutros</a> to his job on a temporary basis in early 2025. Chicago’s U.S. District Court judges then <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2025/07/25/chicagos-federal-judges-choose-andrew-boutros-as-top-prosecutor" target="_blank" >picked him to serve</a> on a more permanent basis once Bondi’s appointment expired.</p><p>Laurie Levenson, a professor at Loyola Law School in Los Angeles, said there are “enormous consequences” when someone is charged with a federal crime. That’s true even if the prosecution is abandoned, Levenson said.</p><p>“Your life gets turned upside down when you’re charged with a federal case,” Levenson said.</p><p>But<b> </b>the greater cost, she said, is to “the credibility of the justice system.”</p><h3>Charges dropped — but damage is done </h3><p>Authorities arrested Collins, 32, and Robledo, 30, on Sept. 27 outside the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement facility in Broadview, which became a hub for fierce protests.</p><p>Three days earlier, a shooter opened fire on an ICE facility<b> </b>in Dallas. Emotions ran high. Without naming the couple, Bovino referred to Collins and Robledo online as “two deranged individuals, armed with pistols.” Users on X shared <a class="Link" href="https://x.com/CMDROpAtLargeCA/status/1972684789028171930" target="_blank" >his social media post</a> 278 times.</p><p>“Don’t find out the hard way,” Bovino wrote.</p><p>Collins and Robledo never faced any charges related to the guns,<b> </b>which they were lawfully carrying and never brandished.</p><p>Instead, a criminal complaint alleged that Robledo ignored commands and pushed back when law enforcement told people to move.</p><p>Once officers began to struggle with Robledo, Collins allegedly yelled at them to get away and charged toward them. The feds said Collins resisted agents — and injured one agent’s thumb. Collins told the Sun-Times he "did not start"<b> </b>the altercation and "did not assault anyone."</p><p>Prosecutors later sought to have the couple detained. U.S. Magistrate Judge Gabriel Fuentes ruled that Robledo didn’t qualify<b> </b>for detention. Collins did, because of the agent’s injury, and Collins’ attorney insisted on an immediate hearing.</p><p>The judge ordered Collins detained. He questioned Collins’ judgment in bringing a gun to an ICE protest, “particularly given ICE’s recent history of aggressive enforcement tactics while heavily armed.”</p><p>Robledo said Collins, who is Black, was seemingly held in jail longer “simply because of the color of his skin.”<b> </b>Collins said he suspects the judge “subconsciously” assumed “I carried and I was a dangerous individual because of my presentation in court, my looks, and the area that I’m from.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" data-embed> <iframe width="200" height="113" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/ADy5XJc9b-Y?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen title="This Chicago couple fought charges brought by the Trump administration — and won"></iframe> </div> </div></div><p>In his written order, Fuentes said the defense request for an immediate hearing left him without a report that might have addressed Collins’ employment and lack of criminal history, as well as his personal background. The decision “was an extremely close call,” the judge wrote.</p><p>Fuentes predicted that a reviewing judge could take advantage of “a more fulsome record.”</p><p>Three days later, U.S. District Judge Sunil Harjani<b> </b>ordered Collins’ release with that additional information in hand.</p><p>Then, on Oct. 8, the feds dropped the charges. A grand jury had refused to indict, in a rare rebuke of federal prosecutors.</p><p>The time spent in jail was “nerve-wracking,” Collins said.</p><p>“Not because I was scared that I was in federal prison,” he explained. “But just the stress of knowing that I can’t take care of my pets, my family. That the justice system does not work even when you haven’t done anything wrong.”</p><p>Robledo has been hesitant to join protests in Broadview ever since. As someone who has been involved in demonstrations since the age of 13, Robledo said that’s “life changing”<b> </b>— but insisted it’s not “life ruining.”</p><p>“It makes it harder for you to do anything,” Robledo said of the prosecution. “That’s the point, right?</p><p>“But I decided a long time ago that that wasn’t going to happen to me.”</p><p>Fuentes has since <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2025/11/20/unusual-and-possibly-unprecedented-judge-calls-out-chicago-feds-as-midway-blitz-cases-fall-apart" target="_blank" >questioned some of the charges</a> brought amid Operation Midway Blitz, including against Collins and Robledo. He did so in an opinion<b> </b>issued in late November, after a series of cases before him<b> </b>fell apart.</p><p>The judge wrote that he’d “obtained sworn confirmation that video backed up”<b> </b>the feds’ claims against Collins and Robledo. Still, he wrote, “the grand jury refused to find probable cause.”</p><p>“That is a sobering event for a magistrate judge,” Fuentes wrote.</p><p>He added: “Any responsible federal prosecutor knows that federal charges, or any actions by the United States attorney directed at the citizenry, must be undertaken with the utmost care.”</p><h3>‘Levels of repression’</h3><p>Martinez has become the most prominent of the 17 cleared Midway Blitz defendants in Chicago. She testified recently <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2026/02/03/marimar-martinez-goes-to-washington-wants-trump-officials-to-admit-not-a-domestic-terrorist" target="_blank" >before Democratic members of Congress</a>. She also <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2026/02/05/marimar-martinez-shot-5-times-by-border-patrol-in-chicago-plans-to-attend-trumps-state-of-the-union" target="_blank" >attended Trump’s State of the Union</a> address Tuesday as a guest of U.S. Rep. Jesus “Chuy” Garcia, an Illinois Democrat.</p><p>But in early October, she found herself recovering from her bullet wounds for one night in the Metropolitan Correctional Center. The 30-year-old Montessori school teacher’s assistant said it was “everything you see in the movies.”</p><p>She said she learned not to trust anyone there,<b> </b>including the guards.</p><p>“I remember, I used to hear the inmates above banging, making beats on the walls,” Martinez said in a recent interview. “It was surreal.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-880001" name="image-880001"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f884aae/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3110x1745+0+0/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb0%2F04%2F1db7d61747f79df87515c45fc1a5%2Fmartinez-260202-005.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/4968696/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3110x1745+0+0/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb0%2F04%2F1db7d61747f79df87515c45fc1a5%2Fmartinez-260202-005.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5b80f98/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3110x1745+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb0%2F04%2F1db7d61747f79df87515c45fc1a5%2Fmartinez-260202-005.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="MARTINEZ_260202-005.jpg" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5b80f98/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3110x1745+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb0%2F04%2F1db7d61747f79df87515c45fc1a5%2Fmartinez-260202-005.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/337601b/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3110x1745+0+0/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb0%2F04%2F1db7d61747f79df87515c45fc1a5%2Fmartinez-260202-005.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5b80f98/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3110x1745+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb0%2F04%2F1db7d61747f79df87515c45fc1a5%2Fmartinez-260202-005.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Marimar Martinez stands in the Chicago Public Media lobby at Navy Pier, Sunday, Feb. 01, 2026. Martinez survived five gunshots from a Border Patrol agent in Chicago last fall. | Candace Dane Chambers/Sun-Times.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Candace Dane Chambers/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Martinez spent 46 days charged with assaulting the Border Patrol agent who shot her, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2026/02/10/marimar-martinez-the-chicago-woman-shot-by-border-patrol-agent-expected-to-file-lawsuit-release-evidence" target="_blank" >Charles Exum</a>. Then, on Nov. 20, federal prosecutors <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2025/11/20/operation-midway-blitz-marimar-martinez-anthony-ruiz-us-supreme-court-feds-drop-case-against-woman-shot-by-border-patrol-agent-in-brighton-park" target="_blank" >abruptly dropped the charges</a> against her and another man, Anthony Ian Santos Ruiz.</p><p>Homeland Security officials labeled Martinez a “domestic terrorist” and have refused to rescind the claim, even though a social media post about Collins and Robledo seems to have disappeared.</p><p>ICE officials did not respond to a request for comment about Collins and Robledo.</p><p>Only one Midway Blitz case <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2026/01/21/bovino-murder-for-hire-trial-moving-fast-at-federal-courthouse-where-itll-soon-be-in-jurors-hands" target="_blank" >has gone to trial</a>, so far. The feds accused Espinoza Martinez, 37, of offering $10,000 for Bovino’s murder. Espinoza Martinez spent 109 days in jail — far more than any other Midway Blitz defendant who's been cleared.</p><p>His prosecution revolved around a Snapchat message he sent to an acquaintance<b> </b>that purportedly offered $2,000 for Bovino’s capture and $10,000 for his head. Espinoza Martinez is a Mexican citizen and father who lived in Chicago for 30 years and has no criminal history, records show.</p><p>He told agents he didn’t mean for anyone to actually carry out the murder.</p><p>The jury found Espinoza Martinez not guilty on Jan. 22. But Homeland Security <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2026/01/24/juan-espinoza-martinez-bovino-murder-plot-ice-custody" target="_blank" >took him into custody<b> </b>the next day</a>, as he was being released from the MCC. He’s still being held in the Clay County Justice Center in Indiana, after an immigration judge found that he posed a “potential”<b> </b>danger to the community.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Juan Espinoza Martinez of Chicago with members of his family.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Provided</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Espinoza Martinez only landed on the feds’ radar because of the Snapchat message he sent, prosecutors said during the trial.</p><p>The consequences for every Midway Blitz defendant haven’t been so severe. But Guataquira, 30, says it shows how people are being targeted by the feds “even at the most ‘minor’ level.”</p><p>For 19 weeks, Guataquira faced a misdemeanor charge alleging she’d impeded a federal employee in Broadview. She told the Sun-Times she was accused of knocking a phone out of an agent’s hand Oct. 3, the day Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem visited the ICE facility.</p><p>Prosecutors finally dropped the case against Guataquira on Feb. 18.</p><p>Guataquira said she was held in custody for about six hours but never overnight. She said she’s since spent her days traveling and never had to attend court in person. She reported to the U.S. Marshals office over the holidays to be processed.</p><p>But authorities took her passport. She said that prevented her from visiting family in Mexico and otherwise crossing the border during her travels.</p><p>“We wanted to go to Vancouver Island when we were in Washington,” Guataquira said. “Could not do any of that. So that was, I think, one of the biggest things that bugged me.”</p><p>It all amounts to “different levels of repression,” she said, “from the legal end of things to your livelihood.”</p><h3>Sullied reputations</h3><p>Levenson, the Loyola law professor, is also a former federal prosecutor. She said Trump’s second term brought significant change to the Justice Department, where top officials seem to be “using the power of prosecution for revenge and retribution.”</p><p>“I think it’s about chilling demonstrators," Levenson said. “It’s about intimidation. It’s about flexing the federal muscle.”</p><p>Even a misdemeanor case like Guataquira’s carries a threat of prison time.</p><p>“All you know is that the government’s being extremely aggressive,” Levenson said. “So you think of the worst.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-floatRight> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a9c6a8c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/396x222+0+0/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F45%2Fb8%2F80bd500849ef927ce982f0843fed%2Flevenson-laurie-new-faculty-photo.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f3b4f73/2147483647/strip/true/crop/396x222+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F45%2Fb8%2F80bd500849ef927ce982f0843fed%2Flevenson-laurie-new-faculty-photo.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Laurie Levenson, professor at Loyola Law School in Los Angeles</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Loyola Law School</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>There’s limited legal recourse available to people caught up in failed federal prosecutions, she said. Meanwhile, the ensuing news coverage damages people’s reputations.</p><p>“What people first see is that you’ve been arrested,” Levenson said. “They often don’t follow the resolution of the case. And so, the name calling that has occurred can have irreparable damage on individuals, even if the case is dismissed. They have a label that is put on them and it’s very hard to get that removed from the public psyche.”</p><p>Levenson said it could “take years to repair any trust in credibility in the Justice Department,” including within the judiciary, following so many failed prosecutions.</p><p>“What really troubles me,” Levenson said, “is there is real crime out there.</p><p>“But if you’re busy spending your time, money, [and] energy on cases where, ultimately, they will be or should be dropped,” she said, “then you’re not protecting society.”</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2026/tracker-federal-prosecutions-chicago-status-trumps-immigration-blitz-ice" target="_blank" >Tracking every known federal prosecution in Chicago tied to Trump’s immigration blitz</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2025/11/20/unusual-and-possibly-unprecedented-judge-calls-out-chicago-feds-as-midway-blitz-cases-fall-apart" target="_blank" >‘Unusual and possibly unprecedented’: Judge calls out Chicago feds as Midway Blitz cases fall apart</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2026/02/03/marimar-martinez-shot-border-patrol-chicago-speaks-out-after-good-pretti-deaths-i-am-their-voice" target="_blank" >Marimar Martinez, shot by Border Patrol in Chicago, speaks out after Good, Pretti deaths: ‘I am their voice’</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p></p>

entries.title: Chicago experiencing 'weather whiplash' as temps in 60s Friday, 30s by Saturday
entries.summary: <p>The Chicago area is experiencing a "weather whiplash" as temperatures are expected to climb well above normal Friday before dropping roughly 30 degrees by Saturday. </p><p>Friday's highs are expected to reach the low-60s in the metro area and could reach the mid-60s in the southwest suburbs before plummeting to the mid-30s by Saturday and struggling to reach the freezing point by Sunday, according to the National Weather Service. </p><p>"Meteorological spring actually starts on March 1, so that's the time of year when we get these big shifts in the temperature," said Brett Borchardt, a meteorologist with the weather service. </p><p>"For this particular setup, there is a low pressure system that's going to be moving along the United States and Canadian border. Since we're on the south side of that system, it's going to be pulling in warm air northward, so we're kind of benefiting from our placement, but that's still going to drive a cold front through our area."</p><p>"Weather whiplashes are pretty common this time of year, and that's just what can be taking place with the system," Borchardt added. </p><p>There are a "couple of chances for snow" Saturday near the Wisconsin state line and Sunday night in the south suburbs, though the metro area may not see much snow.</p><p>"It won't be slam dunks for everybody," Borchardt said of the snow probabilities. </p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Warren's Jaxson Davis named 2026 Chicago Sun-Times Player of the Year
entries.summary: <p>Jaxson Davis's scoring and the passing abilities grab headlines, but those skills are not what make the Sun-Times Player of the Year special.</p><p>Warren’s 6-1 junior point guard plays with a unique sense of calm and confidence. It’s been there since he stepped on the court as a freshman.</p><p>“He can’t get sped up,” Jaxson’s dad Brian Davis said. “He plays at his own pace. That’s his superpower that most people don’t have.”</p><p>Davis has a rare comfort level on the court for a 17-year-old, and it didn’t happen by chance. He spent thousands of hours of his childhood at Joy of the Game in Deerfield.</p><p>Brian Davis worked as president of the large basketball facility and as a coach for the Rising Stars club team.</p><p>“There is no doubt that was very important,” Brian Davis said. “I was working there all the time, mornings to evenings. My wife went back to work and Jaxson lived at Joy of the Game, basically. He was at all my practices, watching the dream team with Jabari Parker and Tommy Hamilton.”</p><p>Family photos from Davis’s childhood show how basketball has always dominated his life. There’s a picture of Davis being held as a baby by Kobe Bryant. Derrick Rose and Jaxson when he was a toddler. A very young Jaxson with Jimmy Butler. Teenage Jaxson with Jalen Brunson.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-410000" Brunson.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Provided by Brian Davis</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“Joy of the Game had a huge impact on me,” Davis said. “I was always there shooting around. Three years old and throwing it up at a 10-foot rim. It just played a huge part in developing my skill set.</p><p>“I remember waking up early on Saturday and Sundays to watch the older guys play. Joy of the Game was a big spot where NBA guys would come in and work out. Seeing those people taught me a lot.”</p><p>Davis led Warren to the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/high-school-basketball/2025/03/15/warren-benet-ihsa-state-championship" >state championship game</a> last year as a sophomore. His confidence, composure and basketball IQ elevated his above-average team into a state title contender the past two seasons.</p><p>“I knew when he was young that he had a chance to play after high school,” Brian Davis said. “He always played up multiple levels, and his IQ was off the charts. He saw things before other players did. That will always be there. But there are things he needs to get better at as far as shooting, taking contact and getting stronger.”</p><p>Davis made headlines with his <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/high-school-basketball/2025/12/30/jaxson-davis-warren-basketball-big-dipper" >51-point performance</a> in the Big Dipper Holiday Tournament championship game in December and is on pace to become the all-time leading scorer in Lake County history and one of the top scorers in state history.</p><p>“That stuff is cool, but I really just want to win the state championship,” Davis said. “That’s my main goal overall.”</p><p>Davis has nearly 20 college scholarship offers, including most of the Big Ten. He’s widely considered a top 40 player in the national Class of 2027 and next year he will be the state’s best hope for a McDonald’s All-American in several years.</p><p>“It has always been a dream of mine to get an offer from a blue blood school,” Davis said. “I still have a lot of time left and they don’t usually get involved until around this spring. I think they will be sniffing around soon.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-bf0000" name="image-bf0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/bbc6fa9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2000x1122+0+0/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb3%2F5c%2Fb36fe7ab41478328571adec9daa2%2Fob-cst-022026-7057-crp.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a9f8863/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2000x1122+0+0/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb3%2F5c%2Fb36fe7ab41478328571adec9daa2%2Fob-cst-022026-7057-crp.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5ce7014/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2000x1122+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb3%2F5c%2Fb36fe7ab41478328571adec9daa2%2Fob-cst-022026-7057-crp.jpg" alt="Jaxson Davis handles the ball against DePaul Prep." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5ce7014/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2000x1122+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb3%2F5c%2Fb36fe7ab41478328571adec9daa2%2Fob-cst-022026-7057-crp.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f2830ce/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2000x1122+0+0/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb3%2F5c%2Fb36fe7ab41478328571adec9daa2%2Fob-cst-022026-7057-crp.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5ce7014/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2000x1122+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb3%2F5c%2Fb36fe7ab41478328571adec9daa2%2Fob-cst-022026-7057-crp.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Jaxson Davis handles the ball against DePaul Prep.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Allen Cunningham/For the Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Unlike many of the area’s high-profile basketball and football stars, Davis has not signed with an agent or focused on NIL yet.</p><p>“That will all come,” Brian Davis said. “We have gotten plenty of phone calls from top agencies. We are just letting him play basketball and be a kid for now.”</p><p>Brian Davis is a varsity assistant coach and the sophomore coach at Warren. Jaxson’s brother plays on the sophomore team, and there are usually 12 to 15 family members at Warren basketball games. The family is supremely focused on winning the state championship that the Blue Devils came so close to last season.</p><p>“Last year the title game against Benet was a roller coaster,” Davis said. “But we learned a lot. It is a huge challenge. Private schools are able to recruit. But we are right there. [This season] <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/high-school-basketball/2026/01/24/benet-basketball-warren-when-sides-collide" >we lost to Benet</a> by seven and <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/high-school-basketball/2026/02/19/depaul-prep-basketball-warren" >DePaul Prep</a> by four and we shot the ball terrible from three in that game. We aren’t that far from where we need to be to win a state championship.”</p><p>Two of Davis’s best friends and the other best local players in the class of 2027, Davion Thompson and Devin Cleveland, left the state for prep schools last year. As of now, Davis plans to stay.</p><p>“I don’t have any reason to leave,” Davis said.</p><p><b>CHICAGO SUN-TIMES PLAYERS OF THE YEAR</b></p><p>2025—<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/high-school-basketball/2025/03/07/davion-thompson-bolingbrook-chicago-sun-times-player-of-the-year" >Davion Thompson, Bolingbrook</a></p><p>2024—<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/high-school-basketball/2024/02/29/morez-johnson-thornton-chicago-sun-times-player-of-the-year-high-school-basketball" target="_blank" >Morez Johnson, Thornton</a></p><p>2023—<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2023/3/3/23622844/jeremy-fears-joliet-west-chicago-sun-times-player-of-the-year-high-school-basketball" target="_blank" >Jeremy Fears Jr., Joliet West</a></p><p>2022—<a class="Link" West</a></p><p>2021—<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2021/4/1/22361356/max-christie-sun-times-player-of-the-year" target="_blank" >Max Christie, Rolling Meadows</a></p><p>2020—<a entries.title: Meet the 2026 Chicago Sun-Times All-Area High School Boys Basketball Team
entries.summary: <p>The All-Area team, comprised of players in the Sun-Times’ entire coverage area, is voted on by a select committee. Players from nearly 400 schools are eligible. More than 150 players were nominated. <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/high-school-basketball/2026/02/11/all-area-nominations-sun-times-high-school-basketball" >Check out the full list.</a></p><hr><p></p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-floatLeft> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-490000"
