entries.author: Michael O'Brien

entries.title: NFL sets salary cap at low end of original forecast, tightening Bears' offseason crunch
entries.summary: <p>INDIANAPOLIS — The NFL salary cap is going up substantially this season, but not quite as high as initially anticipated. That could make things slightly tougher for <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >the Bears</a> as they try to navigate what already was going to be a tight cap crunch.</p><p>The league set the cap at $301.2 million Friday, which is an increase of $22 million from last season and a staggering $76.4 million jump from where it stood in 2023. However, it was at the bottom end of the projected range the league gave teams a month ago when it said to plan for between $301.2 and $305.7 million.</p><p>A few million dollars isn’t earth-shattering in this world, but for a team counting every penny like the Bears, it makes their offseason a bit more challenging. The final number means they’re now $6.4 million over the cap, which they need to fix by the start of the new league year March 11.</p><p>Getting themselves cap-compliant is relatively easy and will be more than solved <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2026/02/25/bears-linebacker-tremaine-edmunds-permission-seek-trade-nfl-cut-salary-cap-15-million" >by the expected trade or release of linebacker Tremaine Edmunds</a>, but the team will need to clear additional space to re-sign priority free agents like safety Kevin Byard, address significant holes in their starting lineup on both sides of the ball and pursue upgrades as they try to exceed what they did last season.</p><p>Most of their highest paid players have multiple years left on their contracts and don’t have an affordable out this offseason.</p><p>Wide receiver DJ Moore, for example, is their most expensive player this season with a cap hit of $28.5 million and is just beginning the contract extension he signed in 2024. Moore is signed through 2029, and the dead-cap number doesn’t drop to a reasonable amount until after the 2027 season.</p><p>The Bears likely will restructure or extend some veteran players to create space, but general manager Ryan Poles is resistant to kicking too much money down the road because, as the team experienced under predecessor Ryan Pace, that eventually leads to an untenable situation.</p><p>I don't know about like limited amount of restructures, but … there's philosophical things that we believe in, in terms of not getting to this place where we're kicking the can down the road on a bunch of guys, and then at some point you got to pay that bill. And you don't want that to be the reason why you're not flexible and able to do unique things or take advantage of opportunities with your roster. </p><p>“There's some things you can do — you all have seen that before I got here,” Poles said this week. “You can accelerate [roster building] and then after, it goes away pretty quick... Do you want to go all in and hurt yourself down the road? Our mindset is to do win now and then be able to sustain that and have flexibility.</p><p>“It's not going to be easy. We've been really good with dead money, [but] at some point that's going to go up because that's just the nature of playing this out over a long period of time and having tough decisions to make.”</p><p>The teams with the most salary-cap space going into next season are the Titans ($94.9 million), Raiders ($89.2 million) and Jets ($88.8 million). The defending champion Seahawks are sixth at $59.6 million, and the Patriots, who lost to them in the Super Bowl, are 10th with $40.4 million.</p>
entries.author: Jason Lieser

entries.title: Rev. Jackson’s death inspires young people to be more present in their community
entries.summary: <p>Nadiyah Spikener’s admits her knowledge of Reverend Jackson L. Jackson is limited, but she says that “it’s her duty to be here with everyone else in the community, and I’m proud to be part of it.”</p><p>Spikener, 24, attended day two of a public service for Reverend Jackson as he lay in repose. She was among hundreds that lined up along Drexel Blvd. from 50th street to 49th street Friday outside Rainbow Push’s headquarters in Kenwood to pay their respects to Jackson, who died Feb. 17.</p><p>Like <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago/2026/02/26/rev-jesse-jackson-lying-in-repose-rainbow-push-chicago" >Thurday’s service which drew thousands of people</a>, photos and videos of notable moments in Rev. Jackson's life played on a screen at the front of the line. His "I am somebody" speech and gospel music blared from loudspeakers.</p><p>During her early education growing up in Naperville, Spikener said she learned about the Civil Rights Movement, though it was mostly focused on Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. and Malcolm X.</p><p>Spikener said that she’s here to “support a legacy that’s been going on throughout the years, way before I was born.”</p><p>She believes that Rev. Jackson’s death may be a catalyst for young people to learn more about their history, have a stronger presence in their communities, and lean towards self-determination.</p><p>“This may be a moment to realize that maybe we need to do more for ourselves, and do more for our community like he has, and just start somewhere.”</p><p>Spikener said it's important to begin early, “whether it’s volunteering, doing side missions, or work, starting in churches.”</p><p>Xavier Myles, 12, came from Flossmoor, IL with his dad to attend today' s services. He knows that without the sacrifices of Rev. Jackson, he might have attended segregated schools.</p><p>“It helps me go to public schools today and I’m in the classroom with white people. I feel proud that we’re not separated like they used to be.”</p><p>Tyler Myles, 31, said Jackson’s enduring legacy will be that he was a champion for all people. She thinks that message is especially important in today’s fraught political moment.</p><p>“There are a a lot of evils and their main agenda is to try to divide us and I think he was very much about trying to bring everyone together for the greater good,” Myles said.</p><p>Myles’ mother Lisa Myles grew up attending Rainbow PUSH coalition’s Saturday morning events. Tyler attended events there, too. Today’s advocates can learn a thing from Jackson’s approach to coalition building and spend more time within communities, she said.</p><p>“Whats different about our time is that I think sometimes with social media and media in general people think that the performative major actions are what drive most of the change," Tyler said. </p><p>She added: "He was out there in communities and for me it's about realizing the struggle is a day to day thing and being out there speaking to your neighbors, getting to know people that live on your block, speaking to the people that are at the grocery store."</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-c20000" name="image-c20000"></a> <picture data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/240f2c8/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fef%2F75%2F596ec2624e53987440ea6be6b399%2F561a1549.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>The Tyler family waits in line to view Rev. Jesse L. Jackson’s body laying in repose on Friday at Rainbow PUSH coalition’s headquarters in Kenwood. From left to right: Micayla, Micah, Lazane and Shemiyah Tyler. </p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vasquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Micah Tyler, 13, and his two sisters traveled from Hazel Crest with their grandmother to pay their respects to Jackson and learn more about him. </p><p>“For a young black man like myself I should take note of what he said,” Micah said, adding that he admired Jackson’s presidential runs and that he told young people that they are ‘somebody.’”</p><p>His sister Shemiyah, 11, said she wanted to learn more about a pastor “who preached very well and taught young black people about history.”</p><p>Their grandmother, Lazane Tyler, said they took the day off from school because she wanted her grandchildren to be a part of history and make memories that they will carry with them.</p><p>“[So] you could say that you were there,” Lazane Tyler said.</p><p><i>This is a developing story and will be updated.</i></p>
entries.author: Emmanuel Camarillo

entries.title: Hombre acusado del asesinato de padre e hijo dueños de joyería en La Villita
entries.summary: <p>Un hombre de Chicago acusado por los asesinatos a tiros de un padre y su hijo, propietarios de una joyería en el vecindario de La Villita, fue arrestado en St. Louis, según la Policía de Chicago.</p><p>Muhammad Thomas, de 35 años, enfrenta nueve cargos, incluidos dos cargos de asesinato en primer grado, tres cargos de robo a mano armada, dos cargos de agresión agravada, robo y secuestro vehicular a mano armada, según la policía.</p><p>Los cargos provienen de tres robos diferentes que abarcan tres años. Se ejecutaron tres órdenes de arresto con su captura. Se le acusa de <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz/2025/11/11/padre-e-hijo-asesinados-en-la-villita-tras-robo-de-su-joyeria-eran-gente-trabajadora" target="_blank" >matar al residente de Berwyn</a> Faustino Álamo, de 63 años, y a su hijo, Luis Ángel Álamo, de 25, durante un robo en su joyería de La Villita.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-f90000" name="module-f90000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>El incidente ocurrió el 8 de noviembre de 2025, y el padre y el hijo persiguieron a Thomas, quien había tomado joyas de la tienda. Faustino Álamo disparó una o dos veces con su propia arma, según un reporte de policía.</p><p>Faustino Álamo fue impactado en el pecho y en el antebrazo izquierdo. Su hijo fue baleado en el pecho y en la pierna izquierda, según el reporte de policía.<br>Thomas también está acusado de disparar y “herir gravemente” a un hombre de 26 años el 28 de julio de 2023, en la cuadra 1700 al oeste de Maypole Avenue, y también enfrenta cargos por un robo a mano armada ocurrido el 16 de julio de 2024, en la cuadra 2300 al oeste de Cermak Road.</p><p>Estaba programado para comparecer ante la corte el viernes.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Chicago murals: Ramova Theatre features South Side artists' work on beer garden wall
entries.summary: <p>When it was time for a new mural at the beer garden outside Bridgeport’s restored Ramova Theatre, owner Emily Nevius says she and her husband, Tyler, wanted artists largely from the South Side.</p><p>Enter <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bridgeport" >Bridgeport</a> artist and chef Won Kim and Pilsen muralist Caesar Perez. They gathered some friends and turned one night last summer into a painting party for both artists and guests at the popular music venue and restaurant.</p><p>The result is a compilation mural about one story tall that stretches the length of the building, with works from nine popular regional artists who freestyled their designs into a mural that captures the essence of the neighborhood, Emily Nevius says. While it’s visible from the street, the mural is best enjoyed from a table outside — in weather warmer than a typical Chicago winter.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-fullBleed> <div class="Figure-credit"><p>Manuel Martinez/WBEZ</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“It’s a really good representation of who we are visually,” Nevius says, with “different voices coming together and creating something unique and special and filling a space.”</p><p>In addition to Won Kim and Perez, those voices include artists who go by the names Cujo Dah, Underseagravy, Elloo, Chucho, Joey D, ZorZorZor and Kuaze.</p><p>Perez, who goes by the artist name CZR PRZ, says he reached out to artists he knew would help build on the vibe that's happening at Ramova Theatre.</p><p>“Those kinds of spaces are what help build community,” he says. “I felt they would be a good fit for what’s going on.”</p><p>Cujo Dah, whose real name is Joe Nelson, is cofounder of Englewood Art’s Collective and a longtime muralist. Perez and Kim invited him, and “if they call me, I’m coming,” he says. His addition included some sketches by his 7-year-old son, as well as an abstract interpretation of his child’s drum machine. The face of a boy with purplish hair — this time not his son — stares out from the wall.</p><p>“It’s kinda random. I try to be a little loose,” Nelson says.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-930000" group of artists who would be comfortable painting in front of an audience. He painted his contribution in his graffiti-letter style. It reads, “Welcome to the South Side.”</p><p>“As a former North Sider, I’m discovering the South Side for what it is,” Kim says. As an artist, “the best walls are on the South Side.”</p><p>Alejandro Martell, who goes by the artist name Underseagravy, says he wasn’t planning to paint that night when he showed up for the event. But an artist backed out last minute, and he stepped in and took that space. He had so much fun he stayed for the show playing afterward in the theater.</p><p>Nevius remembers Martell asking her if his black and white image of a fuzzy demon with a nose chain and terrarium belly was “too dark and scary for the kids, and I said, 'No, this is what they’re drawn to.'”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure entries.title: What's your favorite music venue in Chicago? Here's what you told us
entries.summary: <p>We asked readers for their favorite Chicago music venue. Here's what you told us, lightly edited for clarity: </p><p>"Lincoln Hall. No bad seats, always good sound and great bands. Bonus points for being within walking distance of my apartment."<br>— Annie Sheeha</p><p>"Reggie's. It's small and intimate with a solid drink section."<br>— Brad Leshyn</p><p>"Metro. Classic venue with top-notch staff and a wide variety of alternative musical acts. Anywhere in the audience makes you feel close to the stage. Every concert I've been to there has run very smoothly."<br>— Nicholas Farrar</p><p>"Daley Center Plaza in the summer when there is the farmers market in concert with the music stage."<br>— Terrence Camodeca</p><p>"They don’t book that many acts, but the Auditorium Theatre elevates any concert to another level."<br>— Larry Synakiewicz</p><p>"Have some old favs, but Salt Shed has become the GOAT. Both inside and outside, it’s a perfect venue. Not crazy big, but big enough for some excellent acts."<br>— Kevin Lyons</p><p>"The Old Town School of Folk Music. The people who work there love music and musicians. Every seat in the house has great sight lines and the acoustics are excellent. It's a warm place with real history."<br>— Lori Beth</p><p>"Chicago Theater, sound is great and view from everywhere."<br>— Tracey Sunde</p><p>"The Jazz Showcase in Printers Row. It's close to being the last stand in Chicago for straight ahead jazz."<br>— Michael Vicari</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/music" >All the Sun-Times music coverage</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/things-to-do" >Read “Things To Do” every week</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p></p>
entries.author: Sun-Times staff

entries.title: Weak Congress takes stage in Trump's 'clown show'
entries.summary: <p>The president wasted no time getting to his <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/columnists/2026/02/25/state-union-speech-trumps-lies-immigrants-america-chicago-natalie-moore" >lies</a>. It started in the first minute, when he claimed that: "When I spoke in this chamber 12 months ago, I had just inherited a nation in crisis, with a stagnant economy, inflation at record levels, a wide-open border, horrendous recruitment for military and police, rampant crime at home and wars and chaos all over the world."</p><p>None of that is truthful. </p><p>Economic growth was actually a bit better during Joe Biden's final year in office (2.8%) than in Trump's first year (2.2%). In March of last year, inflation was not at "record levels"; it was 2.8% (in terms of percent change over the previous 12 months). Yes, it had surged to 9.1% in 2022, but it had been trending down since then. Nor was that 9.1% "the worst inflation in the history of our country," as Trump knows perfectly well, because he lived through the 1970s and '80s, when inflation reached 13.5%.</p><p>There was a rise in encounters at the border under Biden, but the actual number of entries — both among those released into the United States and "got aways" — is estimated to have been about 4.2 million. That's 4.2 million, not the 20 million this administration constantly claims. Nor is there a shred of evidence that other nations were dumping their criminal and mentally ill populations at our borders. Nor is it the case that immigrants commit more crime than native born Americans. It's the opposite. No, other nations have not committed to invest "$18 trillion" in the U.S., nor do foreigners pay American tariffs, nor will tariffs replace the income tax. Here's when you start digging your fingernails into your palms. It's fact-check purgatory. Still, as contemptible as the compulsive lying is, the State of the Union highlighted another deformation of our republic that has reached its apotheosis in Trump: the assumption of presidential supremacy.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-640000" name="module-640000"></a> <div class="RichTextSidebarModule-title">Columnist </div> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Columnist</div> </div><p>Take even the format of the speech itself. The president stands physically above the members of Congress, the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the justices of the Supreme Court. This isn't usually a problem when presidents are not maniacal narcissists. But now it feeds the pathology.</p><p>Few take note of the fact that the president is the invited guest of the Congress, not the other way around. The Constitution requires that the president "shall from time to time give to the Congress Information of the State of the Union." It doesn't require that he do so annually, nor does it require a live speech. Presidents starting with Thomas Jefferson sent their messages in writing.</p><p>Woodrow Wilson reverted to the George Washington/John Adams tradition of a spoken, in-person address. Calvin Coolidge was the first president to broadcast his. Congress has the power to insist upon the Jeffersonian practice.</p><p>People often refer to "co-equal" branches of government. That's not right. Though you wouldn't know it to watch its invertebrate current members, Congress is the preeminent branch — that's why it is established in Article I of the Constitution. Congress is granted the lion's share of federal authority, and it has more power over the other branches than they have over it. The president's only check on Congress is the veto, which can be overridden. </p><p>But Congress can impeach and remove the president (and judges), confirm or reject executive and judicial appointees, strip courts of jurisdiction or even disestablish them, coin money, levy taxes and tariffs (as the Supreme Court recently reminded us), restructure or eliminate executive agencies, and most saliently, fund or defund the entire government. As James Madison put it in Federalist No. 51: "In republican government, the legislative authority necessarily predominates."</p><p>As everyone knows, Congress has been ceding its power to the executive for decades. This suited members' interest in that it allowed them to avoid having to explain tough votes to their constituents. Now that the presidency is in the hands of a political arsonist, perhaps even these lawmakers can perceive where their cowardice has led.</p><p>It's true that presidents have flexed their war-making muscles on many occasions, successfully bypassing congressional power. But presidential assertions of dominance have only been possible when Congress emasculates itself. It will take time for members to recover their self-respect. A few have introduced war powers resolutions, but the overall tone regarding Trump's possible plans for Iran remains tentative, almost pleading.</p><p>Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer said, "Look, this is serious, and the administration has to make its case to the American people." House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries observed, reasonably enough, that he couldn't understand the urgency regarding Iran's nuclear program, since the administration claimed in June that it had "obliterated" the threat. But he offered only that "the American people deserve an explanation."</p><p>State of the Union addresses have long since devolved into kabuki theater with members bobbing in and out of their seats like Whac-A-Mole. But under Trump, they've become clown shows — and though Trump himself is chief clown, the members too have been smeared in greasepaint. Until they can reclaim their dignity, the show should be put on hiatus.</p><p><i>Mona Charen is policy editor of The Bulwark and host of the “Beg to Differ” podcast.</i></p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-000000" name="module-000000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Send letters to <a class="Link" href="mailto:letters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >letters@suntimes.com</a>. More about <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/submitting-opinion-and-letters" >how to submit here</a>.</div> </div><p></p>
entries.author: Mona Charen

entries.title: Bears QB Caleb Williams does signature celebration in new music video
entries.summary: <p>Caleb Williams did his “Iceman” celebration in a new rap video.</p><p>The <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >Bears</a> quarterback appears in the video for “Made It On Our Own” by Los Angeles-based rapper Yeat and EsDeeKid. About halfway through the video, Williams stepped out from the back of a backlit shipping truck and rubbed his biceps with his hands, the same “Iceman” celebration he used last season after Bears touchdowns. Later, he's shown throwing a football. The video was shot at Drake's mansion.</p><p>The celebration is reminiscent of what Chelsea soccer player Cole Palmer does after scoring goals.</p><p>Yeat and Williams are friendly; the rapper brought the Bears quarterback on stage at Summer Smash in June.</p><p></p><p>Williams has had an fun-loving offseason, starting with consecutive appearances alongside Cubs outfielder Pete Crow-Armstrong at Blackhawks and Bulls games after the season ended. He participated in a celebrity three-point contest two days before the NBA All-Star Game earlier this month in Los Angeles.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" > <div class="TweetUrl"> <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr"><a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/Bears?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">#Bears</a> QB Caleb Williams throws a football and does his "Iceman" Celebration in Yeat's new video "Made It On Our Own." <a href="https://t.co/nvWuN0UW0F">pic.twitter.com/nvWuN0UW0F</a></p>— Patrick Finley (@patrickfinley) <a href="https://twitter.com/patrickfinley/status/2027402999371305214?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 27, 2026</a></blockquote> <script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script> </div> </div> </div></div><p>Before the contest, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2026/02/26/bears-coach-ben-johnson-gets-a-grade-leaked-nflpa-survey-george-mccaskey-ryan-poles-nfl" target="_blank" >Bears coach Ben Johnson</a> sent Williams a meme of someone missing shots.</p><p>“When it actually happened, I felt bad,” Johnson said with a smile this week. “Spoke that into existence, didn’t I?”</p>
entries.author: Patrick Finley

entries.title: Protesters keep beating Trump in federal court
entries.summary: <h3>Good morning, Chicago. ✶</h3><h3></h3><p>🔎 <b>Below</b>: Cases against 17 of 32 people charged with nonimmigration crimes during Operation Midway Blitz have collapsed, and no one has been convicted. Still, these legal battles are taking a toll on the Chicagoans involved.</p><p>🗞️ <b>Plus</b>: More than 500 students will be displaced by school closings, Chicago's 311 "black hole" and more news you need to know.</p><p>📝 <b>Keeping score</b>: <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-j/" target="_blank" >The Bulls fell to the Trail Blazers</a>, 121-112 — their 11th-straight loss; <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-t/" target="_blank" >the Blackhawks were bested by the Predators</a>, 4-2.</p><p>☑️ <b>Coming Sunday</b>: Our guide to this year's primary election will hit newsstands, and your inbox via a special edition of this newsletter, on Sunday.</p><p>📧 <b>Subscribe</b>: <a class="Link" href="https://newsletter-hub.suntimes.com/" target="_blank" >Get this newsletter delivered to your inbox weekday mornings.</a></p><p>⏱️: <i>An 8-minute read</i></p><hr><p></p><h4>TODAY’S WEATHER class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Jocelyne Robledo and Ray Collins.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-d/" target="_blank" >ICE protesters keep beating Trump in Chicago federal court, but battles take toll</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-h/" target="_blank" >Jon Seidel</a></h5><p>After the charges: A growing number of protesters have been left to pick up the pieces after taking on President Donald Trump's administration and U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement in court — and winning.</p><p>No teeth: Prosecutions for nonimmigration crimes tied to Operation Midway Blitz have disintegrated at an alarming rate at the Dirksen Federal Courthouse since October. Cases against 17 of 32 known defendants <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-k/" target="_blank" >have already collapsed</a>.</p><p>The toll: The cases still have a cost. A federal prosecution is intimidating. It carries the threat of prison time. Damaging news stories spread online. Freedoms are often restricted. Lawyers are needed, though federal defenders have saved people from big legal bills. Then there’s jail — the 17 cleared defendants spent a combined 150 days in federal custody, records show.</p><p>Zooming in: Jocelyne Robledo and Ray Collins were charged last fall with assaulting federal officers. A grand jury refused to indict the couple, and prosecutors wound up dropping the charges. "It’s almost embarrassing," Collins said about having to tell potential employers he was arrested for a felony. But he's resilient. "I know myself and my character, that those things would never stick ... They can’t tarnish what I’ve done in my community. They can’t tarnish who I am as a person."</p><p><b>Related headlines</b>: <br></p><ul class="rte2-style-ul" style="line-height: inherit; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px; margin-left: 24px; padding: 0px; list-style-type: disc;" id="rte-b70f1513-13ea-11f1-bfa3-a1af6000e9e8"><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-u/" target="_blank" >As Midway Blitz cases collapse, ‘Broadview Six’ prosecutors agree to scale back controversial indictment</a></li><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-o/" target="_blank" >The IRS broke the law by disclosing confidential information to ICE 42,695 times, judge says</a></li></ul><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-b/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4>REV. JESSE JACKSON ✶</h4><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-e40000" name="image-e40000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/501e3c6/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7526x4224+0+0/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa7%2F84%2Fcdeb59a74880b0a38a1735e9f991%2Fjjreposethurs-260227-42.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7a628a9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7526x4224+0+0/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa7%2F84%2Fcdeb59a74880b0a38a1735e9f991%2Fjjreposethurs-260227-42.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/15e15de/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7526x4224+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa7%2F84%2Fcdeb59a74880b0a38a1735e9f991%2Fjjreposethurs-260227-42.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Mourners chant “I am!” while waiting in line to enter the Rainbow PUSH Coalition to pay their respects to Rev. Jesse Jackson as he lies in repose at his South Side nonprofit, Thursday, Feb. 26, 2026. | Ashlee Rezin/Sun-Times" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/15e15de/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7526x4224+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa7%2F84%2Fcdeb59a74880b0a38a1735e9f991%2Fjjreposethurs-260227-42.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/db6793c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7526x4224+0+0/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa7%2F84%2Fcdeb59a74880b0a38a1735e9f991%2Fjjreposethurs-260227-42.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/15e15de/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7526x4224+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa7%2F84%2Fcdeb59a74880b0a38a1735e9f991%2Fjjreposethurs-260227-42.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Mourners and supporters line up Thursday outside Rainbow PUSH in Kenwood to pay their respects to the Rev. Jesse Jackson.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Ashlee Rezin/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-n/" target="_blank" >Thousands gather to view Jesse Jackson and reflect on his impact</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-p/" target="_blank" >Erica Thompson</a>, <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-x/" target="_blank" >Cindy Hernandez</a> and <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-m/" target="_blank" >Somer Van Benton</a></h5><p><b>Honoring Jackson</b>: Politicians, family members and thousands of other admirers of all ages walked through the doors of Rainbow PUSH Coalition in Kenwood on Thursday to pay their respects to the Rev. Jesse Jackson. The celebrated civil rights leader, who died at 84 on Feb. 17, lay in repose in the historic nonprofit’s sanctuary throughout the day.</p><p><b>Elders reflect</b>: Older community members on Thursday took pride in saying they'd followed Jackson's impact over several decades. Whether it was seeing media coverage of him with the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. or hearing him speak at their high schools, they said their experiences had a profound effect on their lives. And they hoped to see his legacy carried forward by the next generation.</p><p><b>Honors inside</b>: Inside the sanctuary, community members gathered with quiet reverence to pay their respects. White flowers, a black and white portrait of Jackson, and U.S., Chicago and pan-African flags decorated the area surrounding the casket. Performers including former members of the Soul Stirrers gospel group sang live throughout the day. A rotating group of religious leaders provided prayers, including Cardinal Blase Cupich, who was accompanied by Father Michael Pfleger.</p><p><b>Outside lines</b>: Scores of people waited along Drexel Avenue in the crisp but sunny weather as recordings of Jackson’s speeches blared from speakers. Many chanted "I am somebody" and "keep hope alive," signature rallying cries of the late reverend.</p><p><b>In their words</b>: "I have a lot of respect and admiration for Rev. Jesse Jackson, for all the great things that he’s done for us as a race of people, and how he fought," said Chicagoan Willie Kelley, 67. "It wasn’t just for Black people; he stood for everybody." <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-c/" target="_blank" >Read more of what supporters said Thursday here</a>.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-q/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4>WATCH: MOURNERS GATHER FOR JACKSON ▶️</h4><div The unprecedented move will disrupt the education of some 545 pupils. More than 90% of the schools' students are Latino and more than two-thirds come from low-income households.</p><p><b>Key context</b>: CPS officials told the financially distressed charter network that it was taking this action to "safeguard students’ educational stability" and to make sure it’s complying with state and federal laws. >Bears property tax incentives advance in Illinois House over city opposition</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-jd/" target="_blank" >Mawa Iqbal</a>, <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-jh/" target="_blank" >Fran Spielman</a> and <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-jk/" target="_blank" >Matt Trunfio</a></h5><p><b>Big play</b>: A tax incentive plan aimed at keeping the Bears in Illinois advanced Thursday in the state House amid opposition from City Hall and questions about whether Democrats can whip up enough votes to pass it.</p><p><b>Key context</b>: The legislation, introduced by state Rep. Kam Buckner, D-Chicago, would allow the NFL team to negotiate a freeze on property tax assessments with local taxing districts — in this case, Arlington Heights, Cook County and local school districts.</p><p><b>Meanwhile, in Indiana</b>: Indiana Gov. Mike Braun <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-ju/" target="_blank" >signed a sprawling tax- incentive plan</a> in hopes of luring the Bears across state lines. It's the latest development in the high-stakes bidding war between Illinois and Indiana over which state can lay claim to one of the NFL’s most storied franchises as the team looks for the exits from its longtime lease at Soldier Field.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-tl/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4>FROM THE PRESS BOX class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Casual wine education at shops like Uvae Kitchen & Wine Bar in Andersonville favors under-the-radar makers and stories.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Giacomo Cain/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-tu/" target="_blank" >Wine shops are on a sellout run with multicultural wine tastings</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-il/" target="_blank" >Maggie Hennessy</a></h5><h5></h5><p>Casual wine education in Chicago these days favors traditionally overlooked and under-the-radar makers and stories, and leans into nerdiness without pretense.</p><p>It jumps headfirst into historical deep dives and tours lesser-known winemaking regions and globe-trotting grapes. It embraces fun, sometimes oddball pairings like funky orange wine with stinky cheese, or blind tastings with a "Heated Rivalry" theme in reference to the buzzy HBO series.</p><p>The wine industry may be struggling, but in Chicago, in-store wine education is alive and evolving beyond lessons rooted in the historic powerhouse regions found in California, France and Spain. There’s a flourishing menu of classes representing viniculture from Baja and Hungary — and they are quickly finding an audience.</p><p>"We’ve done, gosh, I don’t know, hundreds, maybe over a thousand events? And pretty much all of them sell out," said Melissa Zeman, owner of BottlesUp!.</p><p>Since opening in 2019, this cheery storefront has hosted weekly classes. They range from cheese pairings and intros to wine from the Republic of Georgia to slightly sillier takes like "Shuck Yourself," which teaches how to marry wine with oysters. </p><p><b>Try for yourself</b>: These eight local shops <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-ir/" target="_blank" >deliver smart Wine 101 lessons</a>.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-iy/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4>YOUR DAILY QUESTION ☕️</h4><h4></h4><p>Yesterday, we asked you: <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-it/" target="_blank" >What do you think about self-driving cars operating in Chicago?</a></p><p>Here’s some of what you said, edited for space and clarity:</p><p>"I do not understand why cities are approving autonomous taxis and delivery services. It increases local unemployment with no economic benefits to the area's economy [that] I can discern. It just seems like a way for big tech companies to funnel money out of Chicago and into their pockets." — <i>Mike McMains</i></p><p>"I am fine with it, but I want them to show why the <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-ii/" target="_blank" >disaster that occurred during the power outage in San Francisco</a> won't happen here. Strangely enough, I was driving across SF during that power outage. Every intersection had a dead Waymo square in the middle of each intersection, screwing up traffic wildly." — <i>Austin Schraudenbach</i></p><p>"Why would we want self-driving cars here? If we want to make the roads safer, we can lower speed limits and reengineer our roads to be friendlier to bikes and pedestrians. If we want to prevent drunk driving, a robot cab won't be cheaper than Uber, Lyft or an old-fashioned taxicab. If we want to improve congestion, we can invest more in transit ... Waymo sounds like a solution looking for a problem." — <i>Benjamin Recchie</i></p><p>"Generally, I'm not in favor of anything that takes away jobs from real people just to enrich shareholders and CEOs who would never dream of driving a cab or driving for a rideshare service, and are pretending they're altruists who care about drunk driving and people with epilepsy. The most equitable, environmentally friendly way to prevent drunk driving is to invest in public transit, but that doesn't make Waymo any money." — <i>Jordan Mainzer</i></p><p>"As a bicyclist and pedestrian, I rely on interacting with [a] driver to confirm that they see me and to agree on who will proceed.  Until the robocar can communicate with pedestrians and cyclists, I don't want them." — <i>Joseph Schuman</i></p><p>"I fear that they will not do well in the winter, when curbs and lane stripes are difficult or impossible to see. Also, breaking conditions are difficult and extremely variable in the winter. And I wonder if they are programmable for Lake Effect snow." — <i>Thomas Medina</i></p><p>"As we continue to take jobs away from people who rely on [work] as taxi drivers or Uber drivers, I can’t help but wonder: At what cost? Does it make our cities better? Do autonomous vehicles make our streets safer? We see the data, and we still think this is a good idea. But I want to be around the first time one of those driverless cars finds itself on Lower Wacker. Good luck with that!" — <i>Shimmy Miller</i></p><hr><p>Thanks for reading the Sun-Times Morning Edition!<br>Got a story you think we missed? <a class="Link" href="mailto:newsletters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >Email us here.</a></p><hr><p><b>Written and curated by</b>: Matt Moore<br><b>Editor</b>: Eydie Cubarrubia</p><hr><p><i>The Chicago Sun-Times is a nonprofit supported by readers like you. Become a member to make stories like these free and available to everyone. Learn more at </i><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjiyuyd-l-id/" target="_blank" ><i>suntimes.com/member</i></a><i>.</i></p>
entries.author: Matt Moore

entries.title: Hawthorne Race Course, a 134-year-old fixture in Chicago area horse racing, files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy
entries.summary: <p>Hawthorne Race Course filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy Friday in an attempt to restructure its debt, attract a new investor and ultimately save the struggling horse racing industry in Illinois.</p><p>The filing comes <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/casinos-gambling/2026/01/28/hawthorne-race-course-illinois-racing-board-license" target="_blank" ><u>a month after</u></a> the Illinois Racing Board suspended the 134-year-old Stickney track’s harness racing license because of financial strains. Horse owners, trainers and breeders have gone unpaid since August, with more than 65 horse owners showing at least $580,000 in bounced checks from Hawthorne since then, according to the Illinois Harness Horsemen’s Association.</p><p>“This is a difficult day for Hawthorne and for my family which has owned Hawthorne for four generations over 117 years, but filing for reorganization is the right thing to do for the Illinois horsemen and for our employees and their families,” said Tim Carey, president and CEO of Hawthorne Race Course.</p><p>The reorganization plan intends to preserve 250 track workers’ jobs and it will prioritize paying the accrued purses to horse owners, the race course said.</p><p>The Illinois Harness Horsemen's Association, which represents harness racers, owners, trainers and breeders, said it learned late Friday morning of Hawthorne's bankruptcy filing. </p><p>"We still do not have all of the details but expect to be in court early next week. We will release more information as soon as possible," the IHHA said in a statement.</p><p>Illinois’ gambling expansion law that passed in 2019 allowed Hawthorne Race Course to add casino games to help boost the flailing horse racing industry. But the race course has struggled to secure financing to ramp up its racino since then, putting the track in a financial crisis. Hawthorne is one of two horse race tracks left in Illinois, the other being in downstate Collinsville. </p><p>The state law also gave Hawthorne power to veto any potential new track within 35 miles of its site.</p><p>“The Debtors have faced substantial financial hardship in recent years,” Carey said, “driven by challenges affecting the horse racing industry in Illinois, initially due to the expansion of casino gaming and later compounded by an increasingly competitive sports betting market, as well as other industry-wide issues, including rising costs and increased regulatory fees related to simultaneously running a troubled business and building a new business.”</p><p>At last month’s Illinois Racing Board meeting, Hawthorne general manager John Walsh said the track had been working with a new financial partner and said they would “have something in place” within a month from then that would have had the track ready for thoroughbred racing in March.</p><p>Thoroughbred racing was scheduled to begin March 29.</p><p>The racing board had already canceled Jan. 3 and 4 harness races at the track for Hawthorne’s failure to submit required surety bonds. Other harness races in February were also canceled.</p><p>Carey said the bankruptcy filing became necessary after Hawthorne’s relationship with its lender and other creditors deteriorated. Other setbacks included Hawthorne’s sports wagering partner canceling its online and mobile sports betting and the discontinuation of some simulcast wagering at horse tracks across the country that resulted in judgments against debtors.</p><p>Hawthorne is working with the financial advisor Getzler Henrich & Associates to request a federal court approval of debtor-in-possession financing to fund its restructuring.</p><p>The bankruptcy declaration indicates a “substantial interest” from buyers and recapitalization partners in Hawthorne’s opportunity to build out its racino, the race course said.</p>
entries.author: Kade Heather

entries.title: CPS aprueba calendarios para los próximos 2 años escolares con un verano más largo
entries.summary: <p>La Junta de Educación de Chicago aprobó el jueves los calendarios académicos para los próximos dos años escolares sin ajustar el final de un trimestre académico para que termine antes de las vacaciones de invierno, como algunos miembros de la junta habían sugerido considerar.</p><p>El primer día de clases de otoño será el 24 de agosto, y el último día será el 11 de junio de 2027. Es el sexto año consecutivo en el que el distrito inicia las clases antes del Día del Trabajo.</p><p>El distrito presentó los calendarios el mes pasado en una reunión de la junta de las Escuelas Públicas de Chicago (CPS), pero buscó más comentarios de los miembros de la comunidad después de que los miembros de la junta plantearan preguntas sobre la programación alrededor de las vacaciones de invierno y el final del segundo trimestre.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-de0000" name="module-de0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>El segundo trimestre académico termina después de las vacaciones de invierno, el 22 de enero de 2027.</p><p>Los miembros de la junta estaban preocupados porque los estudiantes, especialmente los de secundaria, no podrían relajarse y desconectar durante sus vacaciones porque estarían preocupados por regresar para las pruebas de fin de trimestre.</p><p>En respuesta, el distrito abrió una encuesta del 21 al 27 de enero para preguntarles a los miembros de la comunidad que eligieran entre tres opciones de calendario: la recomendada por el distrito y dos que habrían comenzado las clases antes en agosto para completar el segundo trimestre antes de las vacaciones de invierno.</p><p>Nicole Milberg, jefa de enseñanza y aprendizaje de CPS, presentó los resultados en una reunión de la junta a principios de este mes. Más de 22,000 personas respondieron, y el 55% prefirió el horario original recomendado por el distrito, dijo.</p><p>Milberg reconoció en esa reunión que no todos estarán satisfechos con el horario.</p><p>“No hay un calendario perfecto, no importa cuántas veces volvamos a la mesa de trabajo. Nunca habrá un calendario que satisfaga las preferencias de todos los interesados”, dijo Milberg.</p><p>El horario permite que los estudiantes <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2026/01/12/chicago-public-schools-releases-2026-2027-calendar-with-longer-summer-break" target="_blank" >disfruten su número típico de días de vacaciones de verano</a> después del receso de sólo 67 días del año pasado.</p><p>El último día del año escolar actual es el 4 de junio, lo que resulta en 81 días de vacaciones antes de que las clases comiencen de nuevo a finales de agosto.</p><p>Las clases comenzaron más tarde en el año escolar 2024-2025 debido a la <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/education/2024/2/1/24058117/cps-calendar-2024-25-school-year-dnc-push-back-date" target="_blank" >Convención Nacional Demócrata</a> (DNC), lo que resultó en un receso más corto. En el verano de 2024, los estudiantes también tuvieron 81 días de receso.</p><p>Para el año escolar 2026-2027, los estudiantes continuarán teniendo una semana libre por el receso del Día de Acción de Gracias, así como un día libre para las elecciones de medio término del Congreso el 3 de noviembre.</p><p>Las vacaciones de invierno están programadas del 21 de diciembre al 1 de enero de 2027, mientras que el receso de primavera será del 22 al 26 de marzo de 2027.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-fa410a" name="image-fa410a"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/24616e4/2147483647/strip/true/crop/813x456+0+56/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F34%2F15%2Fd9edf7724613b62ec0e91bce8ef9%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-26-142544.png del año escolar 2027-2028 está previsto para el 23 de agosto de 2027, y el último día será el 9 de junio de 2028.</p><p>Cada uno de los calendarios recién aprobados suma 176 días de asistencia estudiantil, con 14 días sin asistencia estudiantil para formación del personal, trabajo de mejora escolar y conferencias de padres y maestros.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>
entries.author: Emmanuel Camarillo

entries.title: Más de 500 estudiantes se verán desplazados por el cierre de las secundarias chárter Aspira
entries.summary: <p>Arichely Medina debería estar pasando los últimos meses de la secundaria asegurándose de que tiene suficiente ayuda financiera y becas para pagar la universidad, y preparándose para el baile de graduación y todas las demás actividades emocionantes que vienen con la graduación.</p><p>En cambio, se está preparando para transferirse a una nueva escuela secundaria, a sólo unos meses de la graduación. Arichely es una de aproximadamente 545 estudiantes que asisten a dos escuelas secundarias administradas por la financieramente afectada red de escuelas chárter Aspira.</p><p>Más del 90% de los estudiantes en estas dos escuelas son latinos, más de dos tercios provienen de familias de bajos ingresos y más de la mitad son estudiantes del idioma inglés.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-d10000" name="module-d10000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>Después de meses de idas y venidas, los funcionarios de las Escuelas Públicas de Chicago (CPS) le están diciendo a los estudiantes que la red no tiene el dinero para llegar al final del año escolar y que deben transferirse antes del inicio del último trimestre “para proteger la estabilidad de su educación”. Si bien hay debate sobre si la culpa es de las CPS o de Aspira, un cierre escolar a mitad de año es prácticamente inaudito.</p><p>Arichely, al igual que otros estudiantes, tiene una larga lista de preocupaciones y preguntas sobre créditos, calificaciones, eventos de último año y graduación. Pero también tiene una preocupación más emocional. Vive lejos de su actual escuela, la Aspira Business and Finance Academy en el vecindario de Avondale, y, si la envían a la escuela de su vecindario, no cree que a muchos de sus amigos les toque ir allí.</p><p>Se describe a sí misma como tímida y se pregunta cómo será entrar a una nueva escuela cuando ya se ha avanzado tres cuartas partes del año.</p><p>“Creo que mi mayor problema es que voy a tener que presentarme a personas que no conozco”, dijo. “Ahora estaré completamente sola, y no tendré a la gente con la que estoy acostumbrada”.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div Milwaukee Ave., en el vecindario de Avondale de Chicago." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/ff9e03c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+50/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa7%2Fdc%2Febd3caf449508a44aa54b742e089%2Faspiraclosing-260227-16.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6db82fb/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+50/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa7%2Fdc%2Febd3caf449508a44aa54b742e089%2Faspiraclosing-260227-16.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/ff9e03c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+50/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa7%2Fdc%2Febd3caf449508a44aa54b742e089%2Faspiraclosing-260227-16.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Un letrero de próximos eventos en peligro cuelga en la puerta del salón de José Torres en la secundaria ASPIRA Business & Finance, ubicada en 2989 N. Milwaukee Ave., en el vecindario de Avondale de Chicago.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3><b>CPS menciona auditoría pendiente </b></h3><p>El jueves se conoció la noticia de que los funcionarios de CPS estaban tomando la decisión de transferir a los estudiantes de las dos escuelas secundarias del lado noroeste administradas por la red de escuelas chárter Aspira. En la reunión del jueves de la Junta de Educación de Chicago, los funcionarios de CPS se dirigieron a los estudiantes antes de explicar su decisión.</p><p>“Este no es el resultado que nadie esperaba”, dijo Zabrina Evans, directora ejecutiva de Innovación e Incubación de CPS. “Entendemos el estrés y la dificultad de las noticias de hoy. Entendemos la incertidumbre y la interrupción que conlleva cambiar de escuela a mitad del año escolar actual”.</p><p>Evans luego explicó que llegar a este punto ha sido “largo y complicado”, pero que, esencialmente, Aspira, al igual que todas las organizaciones chárter, acordó operar una escuela con el dinero proporcionado por CPS y que Aspira no ha podido hacerlo.</p><p>“CPS proporciona financiamiento y apoyo, y los operadores chárter ofrecen servicios educativos a los estudiantes”, destacó. No sólo Aspira ha sido incapaz de demostrar al distrito escolar que puede proporcionar esos servicios educativos hasta junio, sino que, además, el operador chárter no ha logrado entregar una auditoría y otros documentos financieros requeridos, agregó.</p><p>También señaló que CPS le ha dado a Aspira $2.25 millones en adelantos en efectivo y, sin embargo, la red aún dice que necesita millones más para pagar a los maestros y al personal.</p><p>CPS está “avanzando con este proceso de transición estudiantil... debido a la grave situación creada por la incapacidad de Aspira de demostrar estabilidad financiera, lo cual pone en riesgo la educación de los estudiantes de Aspira”, dijo.</p><p>Hasta la noche del miércoles, el director ejecutivo de Aspira, Edgar López, parecía esperanzado de que podía salvar las escuelas. Les dijo a CPS que se estaba reuniendo con un banco para obtener un préstamo puente y que estaba considerando recaudar fondos, incluso una campaña de financiamiento colectivo.</p><p>Pero hablando en la reunión de la junta, López culpó a CPS por los problemas financieros de las escuelas chárter. Dijo que las chárter obtienen el 83% de lo que reciben las escuelas de CPS administradas por el distrito, aunque los funcionarios del distrito escolar refutan esa cifra.</p><p>“Siento que las escuelas chárter son los hijastros de CPS”, dijo. “Nuestras familias pagan impuestos igual que todas las demás familias”.</p><p>López también ha acusado a CPS de debilitar las escuelas chárter a través de su proceso de solicitud para las escuelas secundarias, priorizando enviar a los estudiantes a las escuelas administradas por el distrito.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-8b7475" name="image-8b7475"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="El director ejecutivo de Aspira, Edgar López, habló con estudiantes de la escuela secundaria Aspira Business & Finance el miércoles. Lopez afirma que los problemas financieros de la red de chárter provienen de la falta crónica de fondos por parte de las Escuelas Públicas de Chicago." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/c0354c8/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fef%2F83%2F8eb201a94aeebfe7bda87ae01f16%2Faspiraclosing-260227-09.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/d902c3e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+0/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fef%2F83%2F8eb201a94aeebfe7bda87ae01f16%2Faspiraclosing-260227-09.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/c0354c8/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fef%2F83%2F8eb201a94aeebfe7bda87ae01f16%2Faspiraclosing-260227-09.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>El director ejecutivo de Aspira, Edgar López, habló con estudiantes de la escuela secundaria Aspira Business & Finance el miércoles. Lopez afirma que los problemas financieros de la red de chárter provienen de la falta crónica de fondos por parte de las Escuelas Públicas de Chicago.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Los presupuestos de las escuelas chárter están estrechamente vinculados a la inscripción de estudiantes y, con una <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/education/2025/09/25/chicago-public-schools-enrollment-drops-restarts-decrease-migrant-students-latino-immigration" target="_blank" >disminución general de la población estudiantil de CPS</a>, las chárter están teniendo problemas para llenar sus salones. Este año, las escuelas secundarias de Aspira comenzaron con menos de 600 estudiantes, unos 200 menos que hace cinco años.</p><p>Los operadores de escuelas chárter también citan otros problemas que han añadido a sus problemas financieros, incluidos los crecientes costos laborales.</p><p>López le dijo a la junta que no se encontrarán “irregularidades” en las finanzas de Aspira y que ha tenido auditorías limpias, pero la del año pasado aún no está completa.</p><p>Hizo un llamado a la junta para mantener la escuela intacta, incluso si eliminan a la administración de Aspira, al menos hasta el final del año escolar.</p><p>“Si esto es por los niños, entonces preocúpense por los niños”, dijo.</p><h3><b>‘Deberíamos estar celebrando nuestro futuro’ </b></h3><p>Arichely y docenas de otros estudiantes y maestros asistieron a la reunión del jueves. Algunos de ellos atribuyeron la culpa a Aspira y a López, mientras que otros dijeron que CPS es responsable y debería hacer más.</p><p>Pero más que nada, lamentaron el hecho de que estaban atrapados en el medio.</p><p>Brian Walsh, quien enseña matemáticas en la Business & Finance Academy, citó un estudio que mostró que los estudiantes tienen más probabilidades de abandonar la escuela, enfrentar violencia y sufrir de depresión después de un cierre escolar a mitad de año.</p><p>Dijo que los maestros como él encontrarán la manera de salir adelante, pero están preocupados por los estudiantes.</p><p>“Necesitamos garantías de que se cuidará a los estudiantes y que enfrentarán la menor fractura posible”, agregó. “CPS necesita darles la dignidad de un plan de acción que no repita la historia. Esta es su responsabilidad, a menos que estén resignados a convertirlos en otra estadística”.</p><p>Los estudiantes expresaron frustración, pero también querían saber qué pasaría después.</p><p>El estudiante de último año, Lavelle Turner, dijo que estaba ansioso por su última temporada jugando en el equipo de béisbol de Aspira y preparándose para hacer exámenes para ver si podía obtener créditos universitarios por clases de colocación avanzada.</p><p>Quería saber si incluso podría jugar béisbol y completar sus clases de colocación avanzada. “No deberíamos tener que pagar y sacrificar nuestro futuro”, dijo. “Deberíamos estar celebrando nuestro futuro”.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/70fff7d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5906x3315+0+227/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc9%2F94%2F136b9652444c9e3ac5d4b0faee12%2Faspiraclosing-260227-38.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Los estudiantes de la escuela chárter Aspira hablan durante una reunión de la junta escolar el jueves en las Escuelas Públicas de Chicago.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Talia Sprague/Chicago Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Arichely está en camino de ir a la Universidad Loyola. Pero ahora se pregunta si graduarse a tiempo y si la transición afectará su capacidad de obtener becas.</p><p>“¿Cómo escribiría una carta de recomendación un maestro que realmente no nos conoce?”, dijo.</p><p>Arichely y otros estudiantes de último año dijeron que estaban desanimados por la idea de que no podrán asistir al almuerzo de graduación, al paseo a Six Flags y al baile de graduación juntos.</p><p>Arichely dijo que ha formado un gran grupo de amigos y esperaba divertirse con ellos, pero si ellos no están en estos eventos, ella no irá.</p><p>“Creo que me sentiría un poco excluida porque no conocería a nadie, y entonces no me sentiría cómoda yendo a un lugar o... participando en una actividad sin mis amigos”, dijo.</p><p>El estudiante de último año, Emilo Zurita, dijo que le preocupa que algunos estudiantes ni siquiera vayan a una nueva escuela, al menos por el resto de este año.</p><p>“He escuchado que dicen que si Aspira cierra, sienten que deberían abandonar [la secundaria] porque no se sienten seguros en otra escuela”, dijo. “Prefieren dejar de asistir que estar en una escuela donde podrían dispararles o que les podría pasar algo”.</p><p>Una advertencia para otras escuelas chárter</p><p>Conrad Timbers-Ausar, el director interino de la cartera de CPS, dijo que está trabajando en un plan de transición que incluye una lista de escuelas secundarias cerca de Aspira que garantizarán un lugar para los estudiantes desplazados. Comentó que estas escuelas tendrán un coordinador de transición designado que se comunicará con los estudiantes.</p><p>También se les ofrecerán “servicios integrales adaptados a las necesidades de los estudiantes, incluyendo mentoría, tutoría, servicios de salud mental y más”, les dijo a los miembros de la junta. “También estarán preparados para proporcionar artículos adicionales como tecnología, uniformes y materiales escolares que los estudiantes puedan necesitar para tener éxito en la escuela”.</p><p>Los estudiantes recibirán tarjetas de autobús de CPS para llegar de manera segura a la escuela y regresar a casa.</p><p>El distrito se asegurará de que los créditos se transfieran y de que los estudiantes puedan completar las clases, dijo. Se les dará a los estudiantes una carta para enviar a las universidades explicando la transferencia.</p><p>Karen Zaccor, miembro de la junta escolar que representa el lado norte, dijo que quiere asegurarse de que los estudiantes puedan participar en los equipos deportivos de primavera. También instruyó a los funcionarios de CPS a considerar la organización de eventos para los estudiantes de último año, como el baile de graduación y la graduación, exclusivamente para estudiantes de Aspira, incluso si ya no están juntos.</p><p>“Creo que necesitamos pensar de manera creativa y asegurarnos de que esas cosas ocurran”, agregó.</p><p>Debby Pope, quien representa a otro distrito del lado norte, calificó la situación como una “experiencia terrible” e “injusta”.</p><p>Pero dijo que espera que esto envíe una advertencia a otras chárter.</p><p>“Tienen que comportarse de manera responsable”, dijo. “Tienen que tener sus finanzas en orden. Tienen que ser transparentes. Tienen que entregar sus auditorías. No podemos hacerle esto a nuestros hijos. Simplemente no está bien”.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" >La Voz Chicago</a></p>
entries.author: Sarah Karp | WBEZ
