entries.title: Nonstop competition for Bears' Caleb Williams as he chases top QBs, fights off upstarts like Fernando Mendoza
entries.summary: <p>INDIANAPOLIS — The <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >Bears</a> were in the Raiders’ shoes at the NFL Scouting Combine just two years ago as they held the No. 1 overall draft pick and hoped to transform their franchise by landing a dynamic quarterback in <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2025/08/31/why-do-so-many-people-hate-bears-qb-caleb-williams-he-answers-exactly-that-question" >Caleb Williams</a>.</p><p>Just as Williams was the runaway top prospect in his class, so is Indiana’s Fernando Mendoza. He’s the reigning Heisman Trophy winner, a freshly crowned national champion and a sure bet to be the top pick in April.</p><p>It’s a reminder to the Bears that they’re far from unique in their aspirations. They’re chasing the established teams, of course, but even as they strive in their rebuild, plenty of competitors are, too. Every year, another team is angling to overtake them in the race to the top, and new quarterbacks will take their shot at surpassing Williams.</p><p>The Titans’ Cam Ward, Giants’ Jaxson Dart and Saints’ Tyler Shough hit the NFL as promising rookies last season, and the latter two already are off to solid starts.</p><p>Now it’s Mendoza’s chance, although he played it humbly Friday at the NFL Scouting Combine by saying he’d be grateful to picked at all, “whether it’s the No. 1 pick or the 199<sup>th</sup> pick,” which was quite different from Williams saying with certainty he’d be the first pick whether it was to the Bears or not.</p><p>Mendoza is the consensus best quarterback, and the top three teams in the draft — Raiders, Jets, Cardinals — need one. He completed 72% of his passes last season, averaged 220.9 yards per game, led the country with 41 touchdown passes and threw just six interceptions.</p><p>“Right now I’m unemployed,” he said with a huge smile. “This is my job interview. I’m just trying to do everything to hopefully get employed April 23.”</p><p>The conversation will get more serious soon. Like Williams, Mendoza will enter the league with the burden of enormous expectations. The wayward Raiders are banking on him to lift them from years of struggling, and part-owner Tom Brady figures to be instrumental in his development.</p><p>Brady is intent on building the Raiders into a winner and was widely seen as the Bears’ top competition to recruit coach Ben Johnson last year. It says a lot if he signs off on Mendoza, and his influence could be just as impactful as Johnson’s has been on Williams.</p><p>“To be mentored by him would mean so much,” said Mendoza, who spoke with Brady via phone during his meeting with the Raiders’ delegation at the combine. “I’ve got to learn a lot. It’s a long journey and to have a mentor like that would be pretty impressive and meaningful.”</p><p>The Bears likely won’t see Mendoza until the 2027 season when they’re slated to play the Raiders in Las Vegas, so he’ll be well into his development by that point.</p><p>He and Williams have faced each other before, actually, as Mendoza mentioned Friday the “tough defeat” in 2023 when he was at Cal and Williams was at USC. Williams threw for 369 yards and two touchdowns to win 50-49 as Mendoza’s pass for a two-point conversion in the final minute was incomplete. Mendoza threw for 292 yards and two touchdowns as a red-shirt freshman.</p><p>If Mendoza elevates the Raiders, they’ll become one more obstacle for the Bears in the harsh ecosystem of the NFL, a zero-sum game in which one team’s gains always come at the expense of another. It’s never as simple as merely finding solutions to your own problems; those solutions have to be better than other teams’ solutions.</p><p>The competition never stops as Williams is trying to prove he’s a top-10 quarterback next season and earn a landmark contract extension to solidify himself as the Bears’ centerpiece. He was better last season under Johnson than he was as a rookie, but his next step needs to be bigger.</p><p>He was top-seven in yards (3,942), touchdown passes (27) and fewest interceptions by percentage (1.2% of his passes), but also finished 22nd in passer rating (90.1) and last in completion percentage (58.1).</p><p>There’s work to do there, and he has to improve better and faster than his peers. He’s trying to catch up to the great quarterbacks, but he also has to stay ahead of others from his own draft class and upstarts like Mendoza.</p>
entries.author: Jason Lieser

entries.title: Finance Committee backs hotel tax hike to rev up tourism in Chicago
entries.summary: <p>Choose Chicago, the city's convention and tourism agency, says it needs more marketing money to rehabilitate a Chicago image tarnished by Immigration and Customs Enforcement raids and high-profile crimes.</p><p>The agency is could get it at the expense of hotel patrons.</p><p>The City Council’s Finance Committee agreed Friday to support the creation of a so-called <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/city-hall/2026/01/14/chicago-downtown-hotel-room-tax-increase-nations-highest-tourism" >Tourism Improvement District</a> and raise the hotel tax on rooms within that district to 19%, the highest in the nation. The current combined city, county and state tax on hotel rooms is 17.5%.</p><p>The voice vote on the measure, which now goes to the full City Council for final approval, was enthusiastic and nearly unanimous.</p><p>Ald. Brian Hopkins (2nd) led the charge for what he called an “easy yes vote,” noting that hotels in all or part of fourteen different wards — including downtown, McCormick Place, the Illinois Medical District and Hyde Park — have volunteered to impose the 1.5 percentage point increase for the next five years. After that, the district would need to be renewed by an oversight board of hotel operators and the City Council.</p><p>“Anyone who has participated in the budget process for the past couple years can’t help but notice how rare and uncommon it is for any sector of our Chicago economy to raise their hand and say, `Please tax me more.’ I can’t think of another example,” Hopkins said.</p><p>Finance Chair Pat Dowell (3rd) said she’s convinced the tourism district and the $40 million in annual revenue it generates will “benefit Chicago greatly.” But her yes vote came with a demand for spending specifics.</p><p>“I’m looking for more information on how you’re going to promote, for example, historic preservation tourism in places like Bronzeville or the Prairie District or Chinatown,” Dowell said. “How are you going to interact with the designated state cultural districts all over the city? How you’re going to support things like the Bud Billiken Day parade and other parades?"</p><p>South Side Ald. David Moore (17th) cast the only no vote to protest the fact that the 1.5 percentage point increase would also be paid by Chicago residents who can’t afford to leave town and might want to treat themselves to a “staycation" by taking a Chicago hotel room.</p><p>“I’m concerned about how this will impact people living in this city and may want to enjoy this city,” Moore said.</p><p>The increase would apply to room rates at hotels with 100 or more rooms that opt in — and are within a designated area of the Greater Central Business District.</p><p>The tax increase is expected to generate $269 million over the next five years. That would double the existing marketing budget for Choose Chicago.</p><p>Revenue would be used to market the city, bankroll incentives and cover bid fees, such as the $1 million required to enter the competition to host the Democratic National Convention. It would level a marketing playing field now tilted in favor of Chicago’s hard-charging convention and tourism competitors.</p><p>The Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority has an annual operating budget of $457 million, according to a comparison prepared by Choose Chicago. That’s followed by Visit Orlando ($116 million), Discover Los Angeles ($62 million), the San Diego Tourism Authority ($56.9 million) and New York’s NYC & Company ($45 million).</p><p>“Our competitors know very well that Chicago is underfunded, and they use it to their advantage not only to attract the same conventions, visitors and events that we’re trying to attract to Chicago, but to lure away our legacy clients that have been coming to Chicago for decades,” Choose Chicago CEO Kristen Reynolds told the Finance Committee. "Our competitors benefit from the negative narratives surrounding our city that we can’t afford to counteract, and they offer lucrative incentives that they know we can’t match.”</p><p></p><p>More than 200 cities have created tourism entertainment districts since San Diego blazed the trail 25 years ago. Chicago is one of the last major convention cities to embrace the idea and needs to do so after a difficult year that included the federal deportation campaign known as “Operation Midway Blitz.”</p><p>“The narrative around our city that was around the globe [showed] tear gas. It scared a lot of people [who] wanted to come to our city,” Reynolds said Friday. “We were writing talking points and talking to every single convention that was worried about their attendees coming, reminding them that this is a safe city, that this is a wonderful city.”</p>
entries.author: Fran Spielman

entries.title: NFL Mock Draft 2.0 — Risers, fallers from the NFL Scouting Combine
entries.summary: <p>INDIANAPOLIS — As sure as Indiana quarterback Fernando Mendoza will be chosen first overall by the Raiders, Ohio State wide receiver Carnell Tate will be the highest Chicago native selected in the April draft. He started his high school career at Marist before transferring to IMG Academy in Florida.</p><p>“Growing up in Chicago was great,” Tate said Friday the NFL Scouting Combine. “It’s a tough city, so you had to learn how to fight. That’s all my life, what I’ve been doing, is fighting.”</p><p>Armed with intel from the Combine, here’s the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2026/02/12/bears-nfl-mock-draft-pick-25-overall-fernando-mendoza-tj-parker-indiana-clemson-april" target="_blank" >Sun-Times’ Mock Draft 2.0 </a>— featuring the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >Bears’</a> pick at No. 25: </p><h3><b>1. Raiders — Indiana QB Fernando Mendoza</b></h3><h3></h3><p>At their Combine meeting, Mendoza was taught one play by head coach Klint Kubiak, complete with progressions and problem-solving tips — and then made Mendoza teach it back to him.</p><h3><b>2. Jets — Texas Tech EDGE David Bailey</b></h3><h3></h3><p>Agreeing to trade Jermaine Johnson to the Titans locks the Jets in at edge rusher here. Bailey helped his cause this week with a 4.5-second 40-yard dash and a 35-inch vertical leap.</p><h3><b>3. Cardinals — Utah T Spencer Fano</b></h3><h3></h3><p>The Cardinals could be the worst team in football next year, which would give them a crack at drafting a franchise quarterback in 2027.</p><h3><b>4. Titans — Miami EDGE Rueben Bain Jr.</b></h3><h3></h3><p>Adding Johnson doesn’t eliminate the need for another defensive end. With Robert Saleh as head coach, the Jets once picked a first-round edge rusher in consecutive years.</p><h3><b>5. Giants — Miami T Francis Mauigoa</b></h3><h3></h3><p>Mauigoa will try to ensure that new coach John Harbaugh runs the ball as efficiently at his new job as he did with the Ravens.</p><h3><b>6. Browns — Ohio State WR Carnell Tate</b></h3><h3></h3><p>Tate said one benefit of joining the team would be the short drive back to Columbus to meet up with old friends and teammates.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" data-embed> <iframe width="113" height="200" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/DIu0dOR5RBg?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen title="Have a day, Carnell Tate"></iframe> </div> </div></div><p></p><h3><b>7. Commanders — Ohio State EDGE Vell Reese</b></h3><h3></h3><p>Reese had an eventful week, saying he was an edge rusher and not an inside linebacker — he played both at OSU — and announcing he’d go by Vell instead of Arvell.</p><h3><b>8. Saints — Arizona State WR Jordyn Tyson</b></h3><h3></h3><p>The Saints’ second-leading wide receiver last year had 293 receiving yards. The Bears, by contrast, had four wideouts with more.</p><h3><b>9. Chiefs — Notre Dame RB Jeremiyah Love</b></h3><h3></h3><p>NFL Network draft analyst Daniel Jeremiah could see the Chiefs trading down unless Love, “the second-best player in the draft,” is available.</p><h3><b>10. Bengals — Ohio State S Caleb Downs</b></h3><h3></h3><p>After posting one of the worst defensive seasons in NFL history, the Bengals get the draft’s surest thing.</p><h3><b>11. Dolphins — Tennessee CB Jermod McCoy</b></h3><h3></h3><p>The Dolphins hold five of the first 90 picks and still could look to trade down. McCoy fills one of many needs.</p><h3><b>12. Cowboys — Auburn EDGE Keldric Faulk</b></h3><h3></h3><p>Devoting a first-round pick to edge rusher after trading Micah Parsons to the Packers makes a kind of only-in-Dallas sense.</p><h3><b>13. Rams (via Falcons) — USC WR Makai Lemon</b></h3><h3></h3><p>He’d thrive in a receiver room alongside the great Puka Nacua and Davante Adams.</p><h3><b>14. Ravens — Miami EDGE Akheem Mesidor</b></h3><h3></h3><p>Mesidor’s motor and production makes him feel like a Raven. He turns 25 before Week 1, though.</p><h3><b>15. Buccaneers — Ohio State LB Sonny Styles</b></h3><h3></h3><p>Styles was a Combine star, jumping 43½ inches, the highest by an off-ball linebacker in 24 years and wowing other drills.</p><h3><b>16. Jets (via Colts) — Alabama QB Ty Simpson</b></h3><h3></h3><p>After the Justin Fields experiment failed, the Jets take a chance on the draft’s second-best quarterback.</p><h3><b>17. Lions — Missouri EDGE Zion Young</b></h3><h3></h3><p>The Lions need a true edge threat opposite Aidan Hutchinson. Young started his college career at Michigan State.</p><h3><b>18. Vikings — Toledo S Emmanuel McNeil-Warren</b></h3><h3></h3><p>If safety Harrison Smith retires, the Vikings would have to find a replacement in free agency or the draft.</p><h3><b>19. Panthers — Clemson EDGE T.J. Parker</b></h3><h3></h3><p>Parker had 11 sacks two years ago but only five of them last season.</p><h3><b>20. Cowboys (via Packers) — LSU CB Mansoor Delane</b></h3><h3></h3><p>He’s a potential top-10 pick and great value. The pick is one of the Cowboys they got for Parsons.</p><h3><b>21. Steelers — Washington WR Denzel Boston</b></h3><h3></h3><p>Aaron Rodgers will tell the Steelers his plans in the next two weeks. New coach Mike McCarthy needs firepower.</p><h3><b>22. Chargers — Penn State G Olaivavega Ioane</b></h3><h3></h3><p>Ioane didn’t allow a sack over his last two college seasons and gave up just three pressures year. That fits a Jim Harbaugh team like a pair of crisp khakis.</p><h3><b>23. Eagles — Utah T Caleb Lomu</b></h3><h3></h3><p>Since the Eagles took star Lane Johnson fourth overall in 2013, they’ve drafted an offensive lineman in Round 1 just once.</p><h3><b>24. Browns (via Jaguars) — Alabama T Kadyn Proctor</b></h3><h3></h3><p>Jeremiah believes the Browns should pick at least one tackle in Round 1 — if not two. Proctor is just 20 is stands a whopping 6-foot-7, 366 pounds.</p><h3><b>25. Bears — Ohio State DT Kayden McDonald</b></h3><h3></h3><p>Pass rush remains the Bears’ biggest need but coach Ben Johnson said he’d be open to drafting an interior defensive lineman in Round 1. McDonald turns 21 in mid-March and was the anchor of a dominant OSU line.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" data-embed> <iframe width="200" height="113" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/l0qCiIaKX4k?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen title="2026 NFL DRAFT HIGHLIGHTS: DL Kayden McDonald | Ohio State Football"></iframe> </div> </div></div><p>Young and Parker would make sense here — but they've been taken. Drafting McDonald is also an acknowledgment that Texas A&M’s Cashius Howell doesn’t fit Dennis Allen’s prototype for defensive end. Howell’s arms measure 30¼ inches long — per Pro Football Focus, the shortest of any NFL Scouting Combine edge rusher since 1999. He stands just 6-foot-2.</p><p>Howell acknowledged the criticism of his arms this week but said that “production has never been a real issue for me.”</p><p>McDonald, who is ESPN analyst Mel Kiper’s top-ranked defensive tackle, was a run-stuffer in college but many <br>believe there’s a pass rush to unlock.</p><p>"On early downs, I can stop the run,” he said this week. “On third downs, I can push the pocket. I'm a complete player."</p><h3><b>26. Bills — </b> <b>Texas A&M EDGE Cashius Howell</b></h3><p>There’s no doubting his production — only two college players have more sacks over the past three years than his 25.</p><h3><b>27. 49ers — Clemson DT Peter Woods</b></h3><h3></h3><p>Like Howell, Woods has short arms. The 49ers need to add defensive line depth.</p><h3><b>28. Texans — Georgia OT Morgan Freeling</b></h3><h3></h3><p>This one takes some projection — Freeling has just 16 starts to his name.</p><h3><b>29. Rams — Clemson CB Avieon Terrell</b></h3><h3></h3><p>Terrell stops his surprise fall and lands with the Rams.</p><h3><b>30. Broncos — Oregon TE Kenyon Sadiq</b></h3><h3></h3><p>We still like teaming Sadiq with Bo Nix, his college quarterback.</p><h3><b>31. Patriots — Notre Dame WR Malachi Fields</b></h3><h3></h3><p>The Patriots will prioritize finding Drake Maye better receiving options.</p><h3><b>32. Seahawks — Oregon S Dillion Thieneman</b></h3><h3></h3><p>He met with the champs at the Combine and came away impressed by their scheme.</p><p></p><bsp-list-loadmore class="PageListH" data-module entries.author: Patrick Finley

entries.title: State Farm auto customers could receive up to $100 one-time payment per vehicle
entries.summary: <p>State Farm will pay $5 billion back to auto insurance customers through a cash dividend, starting this summer. It will make one-time payments averaging $100 per vehicle to qualifying customers, the Bloomington-based insurance giant said on Thursday in a news release.</p><p>The dividend is due to “stronger than expected underwriting performance, which has been reported industry wide,” it said in a news release.</p><p>It’s the largest dividend in State Farm’s history and will apply to more than 49 million vehicles insured by the company, but payments will vary by state and premiums paid. It didn’t specify how many Illinois customers are eligible, nor the average dividend payment.</p><p>The company also lowered auto insurance rates in 40 states by an average of 10% in recent months, due to decreasing auto repair costs and fewer collisions in 2025. The lower rates, including in Illinois, represent $4.6 billion in premium savings to customers.</p><p>The news comes weeks after State Farm CEO Jon Farney wrote Gov. JB Pritzker in January to push against legislation aimed at curbing insurance premium hikes, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/illinois-governor/2026/01/23/pritzker-pushes-back-at-state-farm-in-escalating-fight-for-tighter-insurance-regulations" target="_blank" ><u>WBEZ</u></a> previously reported.</p><p>Pritzker and other Democrats have been seeking a legislative remedy to State Farm home insurance premium increases <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2025/07/16/illinois-leaders-attack-state-farm-as-it-hikes-home-insurance-rates" target="_blank" ><u>last summer</u></a> that averaged 27%, jolting homeowners with massive sticker shock. In January, Farney said the state’s proposals would “destroy Illinois’ current healthy insurance market.”</p><p>Under a stalled legislative plan that Pritzker wants to revive, insurers like State Farm could still propose whatever premium increases they want, but state insurance regulators would be empowered to force consumer refunds if the price hikes are deemed “unfair or excessive.”</p><p>Pritzker said eight states have regulatory frameworks in place similar to what he’s pushing and 41 have more restrictive standards.</p><p>State Farm is one of Illinois’ largest employers with 21,000 workers at its Bloomington headquarters and agents across the state, according to Farney’s January letter. The company has about 65,000 employees total and more than 19,200 agent offices.</p>
entries.author: Amy Yee

entries.title: Growing healthy food to narrow Chicago's 20-year life expectancy gap: ‘If we eat better, we do better’
entries.summary: <p>Angela Taylor sits on a bench in her garden and looks out at a sea of green with bursts of color: leafy kale, round melons, red peppers and orange marigolds. A few butterflies flutter to the soundtrack of chirping birds and the roar of the L train nearby.</p><p>This garden takes up two city lots and is next door to Taylor’s house in West Garfield Park on Chicago’s West Side. This is where she comes for stress relief, while also nourishing her community.</p><p>“I'm a firm believer that if we eat better, we do better and we can live better,” says Taylor, 66, on a hot sunny day last fall. “Those things come along hand in hand. In our community here, it’s a struggle to eat well.”</p><p>Taylor and her husband Sammie have managed their Fulton Street Flower and Vegetable Garden for about 20 years. It’s part of the <a class="Link" href="https://www.gpcommunitycouncil.org/programs/garden-network" target="_blank" ><u>Garfield Park Garden Network</u>,</a> one of several programs run by the nonprofit Garfield Park Community Council. Angela Taylor is the wellness director there, helping to oversee the network.<a class="Link" href="https://www.gpcommunitycouncil.org/programs/garden-network" target="_blank" ><u> </u></a></p><div 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5ff5f10/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F69%2F27%2F534b2275454fadf4326529f81a97%2Fdeathgap-chicagogarden-1107250019.JPG 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/63556a9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F69%2F27%2F534b2275454fadf4326529f81a97%2Fdeathgap-chicagogarden-1107250019.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Angela and Sammie Taylor in the community garden next to their home. It’s one of several efforts to increase access to fresh food on the West Side, to help close the stark life expectancy gap in Chicago.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Manuel Martinez/WBEZ</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Fruits and vegetables grown at 12 community gardens, managed by everyday residents or a school, are sold every other week from roughly June through October at the Council’s Neighborhood Market, as customers swap recipes on how to prepare the produce they just bought. For $25 a year, people can grow their own food in a raised bed in the Taylors’ garden, creating not just future meals, but stronger bonds between neighbors.</p><p>This homegrown solution aims to try to make healthy food more accessible in a community where people are expected to die earlier than in any other neighborhood in Chicago. Chronic conditions including heart disease and cancer are leading<b> </b>drivers of the stark <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/health-medicine/2025/11/20/death-gap-racial-life-expectancy-gap-west-garfield-park-heart-disease-cancer-homicide-opioid-overdose-chicago-west-side-loop" target="_blank" ><u>20-year life expectancy gap</u></a> across the city. Stress plays a major role. Many of these deaths are preventable.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-eb0000" name="html-embed-module-eb0000"></a><div class="flourish-embed flourish-chart" data-src="visualisation/26291616"><script src="https://public.flourish.studio/resources/embed.js"></script><noscript><img src="https://public.flourish.studio/visualisation/26291616/thumbnail" width="100%" alt="chart visualization" /></noscript></div> </div> </div><p>The so-called death gap is the widest between West Garfield Park, where most people are Black and can expect to live until 67, and the Loop, where the majority are white and can expect to live until they’re 87.</p><p>Heart disease and cancer often strike multiple people in the same family, including Angela Taylor. She has lost three relatives to cancer. The oldest was 60. It was devastating — here one day and gone the next, Taylor says. She’s also had her own health issues. She came down with a vitamin deficiency a few years ago that landed her in the hospital for about nine weeks.</p><p>“It was a really dark place that sickness took me to,” Taylor says, crediting her work in the community for helping her to recover.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-4a0000" name="html-embed-module-4a0000"></a><div class="cpm-gfx-maps-combo"> <h3>Heart disease, cancer deaths are highest on the West and South sides</h3> <p>Deaths from chronic conditions, including heart disease and cancer, are among the biggest factors driving Chicago’s 10.6‑year life expectancy gap between Black residents and other races.</p> <div class="cpm-gfx-maps-2up"> <div class="cpm-gfx-map"> <div class="flourish-embed flourish-chart" data-src="visualisation/27815572"><script src="https://public.flourish.studio/resources/embed.js"></script><noscript><img src="https://public.flourish.studio/visualisation/27815572/thumbnail" width="100%" alt="visualization" /></noscript></div> </div> <div class="cpm-gfx-map"> <div class="flourish-embed flourish-chart" data-src="visualisation/27763463"><script src="https://public.flourish.studio/resources/embed.js"></script><noscript><img src="https://public.flourish.studio/visualisation/27763463/thumbnail" width="100%" alt="visualization" /></noscript></div> </div> </div> </div> <style> .cpm-gfx-maps-combo h3 { font-family: proxima-nova, Arial, sans-serif; font-size: clamp(2.2rem, 3.5vw, 2rem); } .cpm-gfx-maps-combo p { font-family: Arial; font-size: 1.8rem; } .cpm-gfx-maps-combo .cpm-gfx-maps-2up { align-items: flex-start; column-gap: 1rem; display: flex; flex-direction: row; flex-wrap: wrap; justify-content: space-between; margin-top: 1rem; } .cpm-gfx-maps-combo .cpm-gfx-maps-2up .cpm-gfx-map { flex: 1 1 auto; } </style> </div> </div><p>WBEZ talked to and surveyed more than 50 people to understand the toll dying prematurely takes on Chicagoans and their communities. Top of mind: more access to fresh food in areas where it can be easier to buy a bag of chips at the corner store than fruits and vegetables. A suggestion: replace liquor stores with grocery stores.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-floatLeft><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-5c0000" 20-year life expectancy gap across Chicago</a> — <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/health-medicine/2025/12/17/west-garfield-park-death-gap-life-expectancy-racial-cancer-heart-disease-racial" >and solutions on the ground in West Garfield Park</a> </div></div> </div><p>In West Garfield Park, it’s common for people to leave the area for basics, including shopping for groceries in the suburbs or in other parts of the city. And it’s routine to find long lines of people waiting for their turn inside a local food pantry, lines that many advocates expect will swell as people <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/health/2026/01/21/new-snap-work-requirements-cook-county-warn-health-consequences-cut-off-congress-donald-trump-food-stamps" target="_blank" ><u>lose financial food assistance</u></a> if they can’t meet expanded <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2026/02/06/walmart-amazon-cps-top-employers-illinois-workers-still-need-snap-benefits-trump-work-requirements-lose-benefits" target="_blank" ><u>government work requirements</u></a>.</p><p>“Food pantries are becoming part of how people survive day to day,” rather than supplementing what they bring home from the grocery store, says Ken Cozzi, executive director of Above and Beyond Food Pantry in West Garfield Park.</p><p>There is a wide-ranging effort to improve access to healthy food on the West Side, to help everyone live longer. The Taylors’ community garden is one piece of it.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Sammie Taylor uses lessons learned growing up on a farm in Mississippi to tend to his community garden in West Garfield Park.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Manuel Martinez/WBEZ</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3>Lessons and memories from the farm </h3><p>Sammie Taylor says he’s a country boy at heart. As a child, he went back and forth between Chicago and his family’s farm in Mississippi. He’s the eighth of 15 kids.</p><p>As he gets up around 6 am most days to tend to his garden, Sammie Taylor says it reminds him of his dad telling him to get up. They would feed hogs and chickens and load the trailer with hay to take to the cows. His large family had a garden, and would even make their own cornmeal. There was little need to go to the store.</p><p>He carries these memories, and lessons learned on the farm, as he works rows of raised beds with the help of high school students and volunteers, teaching them how to grow and harvest vegetables and fruits, compost and recycle seeds.</p><p>“This is nothing new to me,” Sammie Taylor says. “It just makes me think about home all the time.”</p><div The produce is typically sold from June to October at the Garfield Park Neighborhood Market.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Manuel Martinez/WBEZ</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>And it’s where he comes to pluck fixings for lunch and dinner. People tell him he doesn’t age. He’s trim and fit, and looks younger than his 71 years.</p><p>“What are you doing for yourself?” he says people ask. “I eat healthy. For the last 20 some years that we’ve been in this garden, I’ve been planting stuff that I really love to eat, like swiss chard and kale and eggplant.”</p><p>During the outdoor market season, Sammie Taylor will harvest produce at his garden, and pick up hundreds of pounds of produce at the other gardens in Garfield Park to sell at the local neighborhood market he and Angela helped start. He loves to see 150 people or so regularly buying fresh food. They often sell out.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-d60000" name="image-d60000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8e30f35/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7846x4403+0+415/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F59%2Fdd%2F40abd7874801a1a6d4d1f3c7a67b%2Fdeathgap-chicagogarden-1107250002.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7ff108f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7846x4403+0+415/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F59%2Fdd%2F40abd7874801a1a6d4d1f3c7a67b%2Fdeathgap-chicagogarden-1107250002.JPG 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f84a0bf/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7846x4403+0+415/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F59%2Fdd%2F40abd7874801a1a6d4d1f3c7a67b%2Fdeathgap-chicagogarden-1107250002.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Sammie Taylor works to winterize one of several community gardens that he supports in the Garfield Park Garden Network on November 07, 2025. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f84a0bf/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7846x4403+0+415/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F59%2Fdd%2F40abd7874801a1a6d4d1f3c7a67b%2Fdeathgap-chicagogarden-1107250002.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/dd4e233/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7846x4403+0+415/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F59%2Fdd%2F40abd7874801a1a6d4d1f3c7a67b%2Fdeathgap-chicagogarden-1107250002.JPG 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f84a0bf/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7846x4403+0+415/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F59%2Fdd%2F40abd7874801a1a6d4d1f3c7a67b%2Fdeathgap-chicagogarden-1107250002.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>For $25 a year, local residents can grow their own food in a raised bed in Sammie and Angela Taylor’s community garden, creating not just future meals but stronger bonds between neighbors.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Manuel Martinez/WBEZ</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>This idea of food as a way to prevent disease and improve health isn’t new, but it’s gaining momentum, says Dr. Dariush Mozaffarian, a cardiologist and director of the Food is Medicine Institute at Tufts University in Boston. Doctors <a class="Link" href="https://www.npr.org/2022/11/28/1139388842/doctors-normally-prescribe-medicine-and-now-some-are-prescribing-meals" target="_blank" ><u>even prescribe</u></a> prepared meals tailored to a patient’s medical condition.</p><p>He sees community gardens as playing a powerful role in changing the narrative and the perception of what’s possible for a community, as a way to become more connected to where your food comes from.</p><h3></h3><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-350000" name="html-embed-module-350000"></a><div class="flourish-embed flourish-map" data-src="visualisation/26290938"><script src="https://public.flourish.studio/resources/embed.js"></script><noscript><img src="https://public.flourish.studio/visualisation/26290938/thumbnail" width="100%" alt="map visualization" /></noscript></div> </div> </div><p>There are other efforts on the West Side to expand access to fresh food. Living Fresh Market in nearby suburban Forest Park has signed a letter of intent to open a grocery store as part of <a class="Link" href="https://www.chicago.gov/city/en/sites/dpd-rfqs-and-rfps/home/west-garfield-park-madison-hamlin.html" target="_blank" ><u>a larger development</u></a> near Madison Street and Hamlin Boulevard in West Garfield Park, where <a class="Link" href="https://blockclubchicago.org/2021/10/29/aldi-abruptly-closes-west-side-grocery-store-angering-residents-already-living-in-food-desert-its-a-dire-situation/" target="_blank" ><u>Aldi abruptly closed</u></a> in 2021. Customers can expect to shop there in about two years, says Christyn Freemon, a community wealth building consultant for Westgate Development Partners, the project developer.</p><p>There is <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/business/2025/02/10/savealot-yellow-banana-city-funding-complaints-overflowing-dumpsters-rats" target="_blank" ><u>a Save A Lot</u></a> in West Garfield Park, but some residents criticize the quality of the food. Jerome Bouyer, vice president of retail operations for the company, says customers should give the store another chance, saying their meat and produce “I think will stand against any competitor.” He added that fresh produce is delivered typically two to three times a week.</p><p>Sales at that Save A Lot have been flat, he says.</p><p>In the meantime, West Side United, a coalition that aims to close the life expectancy gap on the West Side, is training and connecting about 20 organizations that work on food access and nutrition, from community gardens to food pantries. They share resources, learn to design surveys for residents to better understand their needs, and receive small grants.</p><p>One organization bought a van to help pick up food, while another is building out a test kitchen to lead food demos for community members, says Elle Lynn Quimpo, program director of the COLLAB Network, an initiative at West Side United.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-b60000" name="html-embed-module-b60000"></a><div class="flourish-embed flourish-chart" data-src="visualisation/26338511"><script src="https://public.flourish.studio/resources/embed.js"></script><noscript><img src="https://public.flourish.studio/visualisation/26338511/thumbnail" width="100%" alt="chart visualization" /></noscript></div> </div> </div><p></p><h3>Looking forward to another growing season</h3><p>Back at the Taylors’ community garden, the annual ritual begins as Angela and Sammie prepare for the next growing season. They are nurturing seedlings — onions, romaine lettuce, blue steak tomatoes and more — in the greenhouse. Cucumbers, cabbages and peppers soon may follow.</p><p>They’ll wait for the threat of frost to subside, typically in May around Mother’s Day, then transplant the seedlings into the raised beds.</p><p>“If it’s closer to home, the better it is for you,” Angela Taylor says.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-460000" name="image-460000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b779053/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F96%2Fe5%2F3171aa3549ce8dfc299b0f5097d5%2Fdeathgap-chicagogarden-1107250005.JPG 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1529b56/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F96%2Fe5%2F3171aa3549ce8dfc299b0f5097d5%2Fdeathgap-chicagogarden-1107250005.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Sammie Taylor in the greenhouse in the community garden next to his home, one of several he supports through the Garfield Park Garden Network." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1529b56/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F96%2Fe5%2F3171aa3549ce8dfc299b0f5097d5%2Fdeathgap-chicagogarden-1107250005.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/d96de43/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F96%2Fe5%2F3171aa3549ce8dfc299b0f5097d5%2Fdeathgap-chicagogarden-1107250005.JPG 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1529b56/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F96%2Fe5%2F3171aa3549ce8dfc299b0f5097d5%2Fdeathgap-chicagogarden-1107250005.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>During the summer and fall, Sammie Taylor harvests produce from his community garden and picks up hundreds of pounds of produce from other gardens in Garfield Park to sell at the local neighborhood market he and his wife, Angela, helped start. He loves seeing 150 people or so regularly buying fresh food. They often sell out.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Manuel Martinez/WBEZ</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Sammie Taylor thinks back to how often they sold out of watermelon last year as he mulls the growing strategy for this year.</p><p>They have another dream: to transform a nearby vacant lot into an orchard where children can play, and where nuts and fruit, like peaches and pears, can grow.</p><p>But for now, they are excited about a buzz in the neighborhood — openings and groundbreakings for new developments, including a massive <a class="Link" href="https://sankofawellnessvillage.org/" target="_blank" ><u>wellness center</u></a> and an <a class="Link" href="https://blockclubchicago.org/2025/09/10/maafa-redemption-project-breaks-ground-on-8-million-community-center-for-west-siders/" target="_blank" ><u>arts and activism center</u></a>.</p><p>Seeing a community up and on its feet is infectious, Angela Taylor says.</p><p>“Those of us that are dedicated to helping to revitalize the community, that’s … hope,” she says.</p><p><i>This story was produced as part of a fellowship with the USC Annenberg Center for Health Journalism, with support from the center’s Engagement Initiative and the Dennis A. Hunt Fund for Health Journalism and National Fellowship Fund.</i></p><p><i>Kristen Schorsch covers the health of the region for WBEZ.</i><br></p>
entries.author: Kristen Schorsch | WBEZ

entries.title: Cubs' Michael Conforto 'motivated' by 2025 dissapointments
entries.summary: <p>MESA, Ariz. – Outfielder <b>Michael Conforto</b>, now in spring training camp with the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs" >Cubs</a> on a minor-league deal, had a tumultuous experience watching the Dodgers' World Series run last year while left off the postseason roster.</p><p>“Super bittersweet, super conflicting feeling, honestly,” he said this week. “Felt like I didn't earn [the World Series title] in a way. But still proud of that group of guys, proud of my ability to continue to be a good teammate and still uplift guys, show up in less ways than I wanted to – but I do still feel like I was a big part of it.</p><p>“But it leaves you hungry. It leaves you motivated. It was something I had to wrestle with through the offseason.”</p><p>Conforto, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs/2026/02/25/cubs-outfielder-michael-conforto-joins-evolving-bench-battle" >in strong position to claim a roster spot out of camp,</a> is pursuing a bounce back after putting together the worst offensive season of his career last year with the Dodgers. He had a .199 batting average in 138 regular season games.</p><p>“Along the way, I lost the discipline in my routine and the things that really prompted the Dodgers to sign me,” Conforto said. “I kind of got away from that stuff and started trying to make adjustments in season, [which] is never a good place to be.”</p><p>Conforto worked this offseason with several instructors, including former super-utility player Howie Kendrick, who emphasized the lower half of Conforto’s swing.</p><p>“I wanted to get back to me, find myself again,” Conforto said. “And I feel great. Part of the reason I'm taking an NRI is because I feel confident, and I feel excited.”</p><p>By joining the Cubs, Conforto reunited with left-hander <b>Matthew Boyd</b>, his former Oregon State University teammate and fellow Seattle-area native.</p><p>“Mike's amazing,” Boyd said Thursday. “Mike's a winner. He won in college, he won in high school – because I've known him that long and longer. And he's another guy that's a natural leader. He's a selfless dude. And it's kind of fun, because I haven't seen him as hungry as he is right now.”</p><h3>Alcántara into game action</h3><p>Cubs outfielder <b>Kevin Alcántara</b> is set to appear in a game for the first time this spring on Saturday, manager <b>Criag Counsell</b> said.</p><p>"You'll see him regularly, but we're just going to be a little cautious,” Counsell said.</p><p>Set to serve as the designated hitter against the Dodgers, Alcántara’s schedule has been a little behind as he continues to ramp up from offseason hernia surgery.</p><p>“We've got plenty of time,” Counsell said. “He's ready to go, he's kind of pushing us, so it's the right time.”</p><h3>Bethancourt reports</h3><p>Cubs catcher <b>Christian Bethancourt</b> reported to camp on Thursday after a lengthy visa-related delay. He then had a full workout scheduled Friday morning. Bethancourt, a non-roster invitee, is scheduled to play Saturday and then leave again to join Team Panama for the World Baseball Classic.</p><p>Bethancourt at least had the advantage of training at home as he waited for the resolution of his visa issues. He’s essentially been playing with the Panama national team in recent weeks, Counsell said.<br></p>
entries.author: Maddie Lee

entries.title: White Sox' Miguel Vargas ready to roll now that he's entrenched at third
entries.summary: <p>GLENDALE, Ariz. — Migual Vargas has played three infield positions and left field during his four-year major league career, but for the 26-year-old Cuban, third base is where it’s at.</p><p>That’s where the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox" >White Sox</a> have him penciled in to play in 2026 and no one is happier about it than Vargas. Except for his father.</p><p>Lazaro Vargas played third base his entire 22-year career in Cuba, with whom he won gold medals at the 1992 and 1996 Olympics.</p><p>“That position has always been special to me,” Miguel Vargas said Friday.</p><p>So is Vargas’ jersey No. 20, which his dad wore, too.</p><p>“When he first saw it, he cried,” Vargas said.</p><p>Vargas remains close to his dad, his daily dominoes opponent during the offseason in Miami. If they talked baseball over the games, Vargas’ best season yet, 2025, probably came up.</p><p>Vargas batted .234/.316/.401 with 16 homers, 32 doubles, 80 runs and 60 RBI in 138 games. He led the team in doubles and runs scored.</p><p>“I achieved a lot of things that I wanted to achieve, especially playing the whole year in the big leagues and staying healthy,” said Vargas, who appeared in 79 games at third base, 69 at first and one in left field. “Helping my team every day was special. It’s hard to stay healthy the whole year in the big leagues.</p><p>“My biggest challenge is to play third base every day. Offensively I want to lower my strikeout rate [17.6%] I wasn’t striking out too much, but nobody likes to strike out.”</p><p>Nobody likes to lose as well, and Vargas is aiming for less of that as well.</p><p>“We have a really good group and I’m excited about this season,” said Vargas, who was 2-for-3 with a double against MacKenzie Gore Friday.</p><p></p><h3><b>Benintendi joins list of hurt outfielders</b></h3><p></p><p>Left fielder Andrew Benintendi was scratched from the lineup with tightness in his right side, joining center fielders Luisangel Acuna and Everson Pereria on the sidelines.</p><p>“Just right side tightness,” manager Will Venable said. “He’s been running around a lot, swinging a lot. Really just precautionary, he said he feels fine. I think he would play if this was the regular season, but just want to be cautious.”</p><p>Acuna sustained a cut above his left eye sliding into second base Wednesday. His helmet became dislodged and caused a gash requiring four stitches.</p><p>Pereria has a right oblique strain and is not expected back soon.</p><p></p><h3><b>Just win, baby</b></h3><p></p><p>Right-hander Erick Fedde, back on the pitching staff after being away for one and a half seasons, echoed what other pitchers are hearing from coaches in camp: Pound the strike zone.</p><p>“They’ve been harping on ‘win the first three,’ ’’ Fedde said. “I’m sure you’ve heard it from other guys. It’s been the heart and soul of the pitching mentality.”</p><p>Winning the first three is throwing strikes on two of the first three pitches. Fedde threw 19 of 29 pitches for strikes over two scoreless innings Friday.</p><p>“The [coaches and staff] share our numbers like, ‘look what you do when you win two out of three and what you do when you don’t win’ it so it’s been a mindset of mine,” Fedde said.</p><p>“Today was let’s attack these guys and the numbers say it’s better, so let’s do it and trust it.”</p><p></p><p></p><h3><b>SOX 3, RANGERS 1 (ss)</b></h3><h3></h3><h3><b>BREWERS 5, SOX 2 (ss)</b></h3><p></p><p>The Sox (5-4) got a home run from LaMonte Wade Jr. and a pair of hits from Miguel Vargas (.384) against the Rangers.</p><p>• Right-hander Mike Vasil, an effective reliever who wants to be considered as a starter, struck out four while allowing two walks and three hits over three innings of one-run ball.</p><p>• On the Sox top prospect watch, top lefty pitching prospect Noah Schultz struck out three and walked none while allowing a run on three hits against the Brewers. Schultz threw 23 of 33 pitches for strikes. Righty Tanner McDougal allowed two runs on four hits and no walks while striking out three over three innings.</p><p></p><p>• On deck: Sox at Guardians, Saturday, 2:05 p.m., Goodyear, CHSN, Shane Smith vs. Tanner Bibee</p><p></p><div class="PageListL" data-module data-hide-authors="true" data-hide-categories="true" data-hide-dates="true" data-show-loadmore="true" ><a class="AnchorLink" entries.author: Daryl Van Schouwen

entries.title: Frank Nazar, rest of Blackhawks youngsters have things to prove during stretch run
entries.summary: <p>DENVER — Frank Nazar remembers how the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks" target="_blank" >Blackhawks</a>' strong finish to last season changed the entire mood of the ensuing offseason.</p><p>Going 4-1-1 in their last six games of 2024-25 — despite the smallness of that sample — gave the team and its fans a <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks/2025/04/14/blackhawks-canadiens-frank-nazar-shootout-ivan-demidov-nhl-debut" target="_blank" >fleeting glimpse</a> of the success they believe lies ahead in bigger portions.</p><p>Entering the final stretch of this season, the second-year Hawks forward is keeping in mind how just a little bit of winning can make a big difference.</p><p>"[We were] having fun, [creating] a lot of optimism coming into the year, and look at the start we had, right?" Nazar said Thursday. "That has a lot of things to do with it. Obviously, everyone wants to have a great end of the season. But when the sun comes out and you get to play hockey while it's nice out in Chicago, that's the best time."</p><p>Nazar, 22, and many of his equally young (or younger) teammates are motivated to prove some things before the April 15 season finale.</p><p>The Hawks' rusty <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks/2026/02/26/blackhawks-connor-bedard-fire-predators-nhl-power-play-quarterback" target="_blank" >4-2 defeat</a> Thursday against the Predators didn't mark a great start to this 25-game run, and their lives won't get any easier Saturday against the Avalanche.</p><p>But as Connor Bedard put it, "every team you play is going to be good" — because "it's a good league." The Hawks will have to figure out how to surpass this steep competition eventually.</p><p>"What I'm focusing on right now is to play the rest of the year the right way and take steps forward, as a group, to become a great hockey team," Nazar said. "It might not happen this year, but if we make steps right now...then coming into next year, we'll be even better."</p><p>For rookie forward Ryan Greene, for example, the coming weeks offer a crucial opportunity to prove he's not only a good-enough temporary option on Bedard's wing — where he has unexpectedly spent much of this season — but a legitimate top-six NHL player for the long haul.</p><p>The arrivals of Anton Frondell and Roman Kantserov will greatly increase competition for those roles. But Greene, also 22, does have one advantage: he's already 59 games along his NHL development curve.</p><p>He admitted he was "running on fumes" before the Olympic break, but he has looked rejuvenated since. He stood out in practices and followed that up with a quality performance Thursday, highlighted by a nifty assist on Bedard's goal.</p><p>"The more [Ryan] can prove he's a guy that can add value to that line, the better off he is, especially as we continue to the future," coach Jeff Blashill said. "There will be different options that we'll have, and he wants to ... show he's the best option."</p><p>For rookie defenseman Sam Rinzel, the end of last season has also been on his mind, because that's when he played his best in the NHL so far.</p><p>This season has been more of a roller coaster, which isn't surprising for a 21-year-old with a <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2026/02/03/blackhawks-sam-rinzel-brainpower-weight-strength-zach-werenski-artyom-levshunov" target="_blank" >less-than-filled-out body</a> trying to compete against pros for 82 games rather than nine. Still, he hopes to demonstrate he can at least climb back to that peak.</p><p>"I knew there were going to be bumps, but [this season] didn't go the way I thought or wanted it to go," Rinzel said. "Getting sent down, as a player, it's really frustrating. I'm happy with ... how I went about it, looking in the mirror and trying to see what I needed to get better at. Nothing has ever been linear for me.</p><p>"If the first half didn't go the way I want, I want to make sure to have a strong second half, so that's fully what I'm focused on. It doesn't have to be a big leap. [I want to] just keep playing smart, playing how I know how to play."</p><p></p><p></p><bsp-list-loadmore class="PageListH" data-module data-hide-authors="true" data-hide-categories="true" entries.author: Ben Pope

entries.title: White Sox need big things from rotation of they want to entertain the notion of being contenders
entries.summary: <p>GLENDALE, Ariz. — For a team that likes to say it’s sitting on the verge of escaping from the land of losses — 100 plus for the last three seasons is where they stayed — the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox" >White Sox</a> aren’t exactly stacked with starting pitching.</p><p>Pitching is still king, and it starts with the starters. There’s no no-brainer choice for Opening Day four weeks from now, and the top three in the projected rotation have an average of 162 major league innings of experience between them.</p><p>In order, Shane Smith, Davis Martin and left-hander Anthony Kay have grips on the top three spots. Erick Fedde, a $1.5 million last-minute addition as a free agent signed before camp opened, is back after getting traded away in 2024 and likely has the fourth spot to lose. Fedde threw two scoreless innings against the Rangers in his spring debut Friday.</p><p>“My mentality this whole time is that spot’s not mine,” Fedde said. “I have to earn it.”</p><p>Sean Burke, the surprise 2025 Opening Day starter who didn’t last the season in the majors, could be the fifth starter. Burke allowed two earned runs on three hits and a walk against the Brewers in a split squad game.</p><p>“It’s a strength that we have a lot of question marks because competition is very high right now,” Martin said.</p><p>The pitching group is closely knit, Martin said, citing another strength. He insists there’s value there.</p><p>“It’s hard to explain but everybody has played with someone, at one level or another, with a starter in your rotation who is hoping you do bad so it makes them look better,” Martin said. “We don’t have that. Everybody celebrates the other guy’s victory and if someone has a bad game, you pick him up. It’s a really big thing. It makes for a lot less toxic environment knowing the guys actually give a crap about you.”</p><p>Lefties Sean Newcomb and Chris Murphy and right-hander Jonathan Cannon also want in on the competition. Mike Vasil wants a chance to get out of the bullpen and be a starter, too.</p><p>Competing against friends in spring training is “weird," Fedde said, but the best rotations he’s been a part of compete against each other.</p><p>“I see that nature in a lot of these guys,” he said.</p><p>But camaraderie and competition within the group only goes so far. After going 60-102 last season, most betting sites set the Sox over/under for wins this season between 64 and 67 while PECOTA’s sabremetric system is kinder, projecting the Sox for 69 victories.</p><p>That would represent improvements of four to nine more wins than last season, decent but not significant in large part because of what the rotation looks like on paper.</p><p>It’s what the Sox have to go with now while top prospects such as first-round lefties Noah Schultz and Hagen Smith get development starts at Triple-A Charlotte.</p><p>“These guys just need to continue to throw strikes, do their thing,” manager Will Venable said. “They’re all working on something different. They just need to command their arsenal, do everything they need to do, control the running game, just continue to throw strikes and we’ll see how it all shakes out at the end of it.”</p><p></p><div entries.title: Man convicted of sex trafficking a teen girl in Lansing
entries.summary: <p>A 40-year-old Chicago man was convicted of federal charges of sex trafficking a teen girl, authorities said on Friday. </p><p>Kennard Cameron was convicted Wednesday of sex trafficking a minor and conspiracy to engage in sex trafficking of a minor. </p><p>Cameron was accused of recruiting and enticing a 15-year-old girl to engage in commercial sex acts in 2023 in a motel in south suburban Lansing.</p><p>Authorities said Cameron photographed the girl wearing lingerie and in the nude. Cameron then posted the photos online and arranged for encounters with individuals who responded to the ads. </p><p>Cameron faces a 10-year to life sentence in federal prison, authorities said. </p>
entries.author: Elleiana Green

entries.title: How Cubs hope to maximize pitcher Edward Cabrera's talents this spring
entries.summary: <p>MESA, Ariz — When a free-agent pitcher signs with the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs" >Cubs</a> organization, he comes in with a good sense of what the team thinks of him, as well as areas the coaching staff believes it can help him improve. Part of free agency was sitting through such presentations.</p><p>Acquired via trade, right-hander Edward Cabrera got none of that.</p><p>He’d known that his name was being bandied about in Marlins trade talks, but <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs/2026/01/07/chicago-cubs-in-serious-talks-with-miamimarlins-to-acquire-rhp-edward-cabrera-mlb-trade" >his landing spot </a>was out of his control. So, much of the early part of spring has been about laying the foundation that he and the Cubs weren’t able to get a head start on.</p><p>“It's different, even the weather,” Cabrera said in the early days of camp, through team interpreter Fredy Quevedo Jr. “But I always try to be on the same page. And I feel really good. I feel really good with the staff here.”</p><p>Cabrera made his first start Cactus League start on Friday, tossing two perfect innings and striking out half of the Guardians batters he faced. </p><p>He’s been juggling so much newness, transitioning into a new organization for the first time in a decade, that the Cubs tried to tailor his ramp-up schedule to what was familiar.</p><p>“It's really just that onboarding process,” pitching coach Tommy Hottovy told the Sun-Times. “Getting to know him, getting to know his routines, what he does in the weight room, the training room, throwing routines, bullpen routines, all those things — and then slow-dosing him information.”</p><p>Hottovy doesn't like to open conversations after live batting practice or games with his observations. He’d rather see what the player is gravitating towards first.</p><p>“He definitely loves attacking the strike zone,” Hottovy said. “He tailors a lot of his identity, I think, in the bullpen work and lives to strikes. And we know if his stuff is in the strike zone, he's really freaking good. I also want him to give himself some credit that he's not going to be perfect all the time and that competitive misses are positive for him.”</p><p>It’s a natural progression coming off of last season, when he cut down his walk rate from 12% the previous year to 8.3%. The next step is to find a little bit of a happy medium.</p><p>The same concept could also contribute to a shift in pitch usage.</p><p>“A lot of his usage was tied to the strike zone,” Hottovy said. “Which is great; he knows what he can throw in the strike zone. Now, I think there's little things we can tweak.”</p><p>Cabrera has long leaned on his 94-mph changeup as his primary pitch. Last year, he threw his curveball second-most, followed by his sinker, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs/2026/01/16/why-cubs-saw-edward-cabrera-answer-long-quest-starting-pitching-jed-hoyer-tommy-hottovy" >which overtook his four-seamer as his most-used fastball</a> because he was more comfortable throwing it for strikes.</p><p>In two innings Friday, however, his four-seamer was his most-used pitch (32%), according to Statcast, followed by his changeup (26%).</p><p>“That's one thing that I want to do, I want to throw it more,” Cabrera said. “And then it can contribute to my other pitches as well.”</p><p>The Cubs also want to make sure Cabrera has a good physical foundation, in part to combat his extensive injury history.</p><p>“We're doing a much better job as an organization when we acquire guys understanding what they've dealt with,” Hottovy said, “diving into the biomechanics as to why we think that might be coming up and if there's anything that we can help fix or help clean up throughout the process. So definitely making sure that strength numbers are in a good place, range of motion, getting just a full diagnostic of who this player is extremely important.”</p><p>High-velocity pitchers like Cabrera tend to be more injury-prone. But the industry has also come to understand that delivery efficiency both will help protect health, and can bump up velocity.</p><p>If the Cubs can keep Cabrera on the field, his stuff and continued strides will raise the rotation’s ceiling.</p><p>Said manager Craig Counsell: “We just think this is a talented pitcher coming into the right part of his career.”</p><p></p><p></p><bsp-listcarousel
