entries.author: Maddie Lee

entries.title: The president, the lies and the cannulated cow
entries.summary: <p>The beauty of getting out into the world, meeting new people and seeing new stuff, is two-fold. First, you learn new information, from the new people you talk to and the new stuff you see. Learning new things is fun.</p><p>And second, you then can apply this new knowledge, making all sorts of interesting connections.</p><p>For instance, struggling to articulate the general numbness of watching President Donald Trump's <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/donald-trump/2026/02/24/president-donald-trump-state-of-the-union-speech-illinois-democrats-boycott" >State of the Union address </a>Tuesday, I remembered a cannulated cow seen at Chicago's High School for Agriculture Sciences in Mount Greenwood (What? You didn't know about either cannulated cows or the ag high school? Well, I'm happy to be the one to tell you.)</p><p>MAGA types, who don't seem at all keen on either new people or new ideas, imagine liberals in some kind of pearl-clutching agony, or door-jamb-gnawing fury. But truly, nearly two hours of the State of the Union speech left me mostly bored. We've heard all this before, many times, from the moment candidate Trump descended that escalator in his monstrous brass and orange stone lobby. </p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-ab0000" name="module-ab0000"></a> <div class="RichTextSidebarModule-title">Opinion bug</div> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h2>Opinion</h2></div> </div><p>"When Mexico sends its people, they're not sending their best," he said. "They're sending people that have lots of problems, and they're bringing those problems with us. They're bringing drugs. They're bringing crime. They're rapists."</p><p>Tuesday was more of the same. When he wasn't lying about the economy or gaslighting — for example, declaring war on fraud — Trump was grinding over the threat of immigrants. Both criminals <i>and</i> bad drivers. That's where I thought of the cannulated cow. How cows digest their food is important to the dairy industry, and one way to keep tabs is to surgically implant a round window into the side of a cow. Students and scientists look through the window, into the cow's stomach, and watch the half-digested mash sloshing around. </p><p>That was the State of the Union speech. The same well-chewed slop of fear, hatred, lies, prejudice, nationalism and enormous self-regard that Trump has been spewing for years.</p><p>One of the many dangers of this moment is exhaustion. The liars lie nonstop, while those familiar with the truth get tired of repeating ourselves, bloodying our fingers scratching at that brick wall.</p><p>Yet scratch we must. So forgive me for belaboring the obvious for the benefit of — well, I'm not sure who at this point. Either you understood long ago or you never will. </p><p>The current war on immigrants is not only morally and economically wrong, but entirely based on lies — haters are cowards, and rather than just admit they're surrendering to fear (of new people and new things) they slur the object of their fixation. They don't hate immigrants because immigrants are criminals; they tar them as criminals because they hate them.</p><p>So, again: Immigrants commit less crime and have fewer traffic accidents than U.S.-born citizens. That makes sense: if you could be deported to some central American hell-hole for a speeding ticket, you'd drive slower too. But let's gild the lily and turn to research: a 2014 Purdue study crunching 24 years of immigration data found that as the population of illegal immigrants in a state increases, DUIs go down.</p><p>“Undocumented persons may be less likely to drive after drinking, or drive at all, because of fear of police surveillance and deportation,” the authors wrote in the American Journal of Public Health.</p><p>Trying wash away the sour contents of the cesspool that the president spattered all over my carpet Tuesday, I remembered the Bad Bunny show two weeks earlier.</p><p>Bad Bunny spoke to me. Well, sang, and not just to me. In Spanish, true, but I understood exactly what he was saying, about his home, Puerto Rico, his joyous, colorful world that includes old people, young people, a rainbow of colors and lifestyles, with joy and dancing. Some 128 million others watched.</p><p>Or 96 million more than endured the president's spew. Only 32 million viewers endured the all-too-familiar speech, as if parking ourselves cross-legged before a front-loading washing machine filled with barf. A spectacle that managed to both sicken and bore at the same time.</p><p>Strange that a halftime music show would offer more hope for the future of our country than a presidential address. Though never mistake hope for action. Those who do not want to spend the rest of our lives consuming enormous helpings of moral chunder are going to have to stay focused and work very hard to settle the nation's stomach. None of it will be fun or easy, and good people are going to continue to suffer and die. But better than the alternative, of mooing quietly while our nation sinks beneath the rising muck.</p>
entries.author: Neil Steinberg

entries.title: Detention hearing delayed for man who allegedly fatally shot 'hardworking' father and son in Little Village
entries.summary: <p>A 35-year-old man who allegedly fatally shot a father and son during an armed robbery of a jewelry store in Little Village last year had two juvenile accomplices, prosecutors said Friday. </p><p>Muhammad Thomas, 35, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/crime/2026/02/26/man-charged-in-slaying-of-father-and-son-in-little-village-shooting-another-in-armed-robberies-berwyn" target="_blank" >is charged with two counts of murder </a>after the attack of 63-year-old Faustino Alamo and his 25-year-old son, Luis Angel Alamo, inside the Joyeria Angelo shop during the Nov. 8th robbery, officials said. </p><p>However, Thomas did not appear in person for his scheduled detention hearing Friday for the alleged killings of the father and son because he was hospitalized at Humboldt Park Health hospital due to a medication issue and narcotics withdrawal, according to prosecutors. </p><p>Additionally, Thomas is facing three counts of armed robbery, two counts of aggravated battery, burglary and armed vehicular hijacking from several separate burglaries and shootings from 2024 and 2023, prosecutors said. </p><p>Another detention hearing was scheduled for Tuesday to formally order Thomas detained, according to Cook County Judge James Vincent Murphy who presided Friday.</p><p>During the brief hearing Friday, prosecutors said Thomas, allegedly along with two juveniles, arrived at the jewelry store in the 3800 block of West 26th Street on Nov. 8 just before 6 p.m. in a stolen Maserati.</p><p>Prosecutors said Thomas was buzzed into the store and used a cellphone to prop open the door before he began breaking into display cases and taking jewelry. The Alamos tried to stop him and followed him outside, according to prosecutors. </p><p>But Thomas pulled out a gun and allegedly shot Luis Angel Alamo, according to prosecutors who added Faustino Alamo then fired off shots using his gun, but did not hit Thomas.</p><p>One of the juveniles waiting in the Maserati jumped out and allegedly shot Faustino Alamo, prosecutors said.</p><p>The bodies of the father and son lay side by side along a curb as traffic continued to drive past, according to surveillance video posted by Telemundo Chicago. Both men were pronounced dead less than an hour later at Mount Sinai Hospital.</p><p>Thomas and the two juveniles allegedly fled and police officers later found the Maserati that had been set on fire, according to prosecutors who added Thomas’ DNA and fingerprints were found inside the store and on the burned Maserati.</p><p>One of the juveniles was later arrested on an unrelated case and allegedly gave detectives information on the Nov. 8 attack. Prosecutors said the juvenile allegedly identified Thomas as one of the shooters.</p><p>Court information and charges for the juveniles was not immediately available.</p><p>Thomas was arrested Tuesday in St. Louis by Chicago police and members of the U.S. Marshals Great Lakes Regional Fugitive Task Force.<br></p>
entries.author: Cindy Hernandez

entries.title: Chicago Loop Alliance unveils Loop Arts District, funding to address vacant stores
entries.summary: <p>The Chicago Loop Alliance announced plans for a new arts district in the Loop, during its annual meeting Friday.</p><p>The district will be supported by nearly 90 Loop arts organizations that will develop the neighborhood as an arts and culture destination. </p><p>“Arts and culture are our economic engine — bringing people back to the streets, filling hotels and restaurants and shaping a downtown people choose for real human connection,” Kemena Brooks, chair of the Chicago Loop Alliance and the Chicago Housing Authority's chief of staff, said.</p><p>Performing arts and cultural institutions drew more than 1.4 million people to the Loop in the fourth quarter of 2025, according to the Loop Alliance. And the economic impact of arts and culture in the fourth quarter was more than $575 million — the highest in the past year.</p><p>Meanwhile, last year's foot traffic was 84% of 2019's traffic that was an estimated 85 million.</p><p>Brooks said the Loop Arts District will elevate the cultural institutions in the neighborhood and reimagine State Street as “a playful, experiential cultural spine." The district is also envisioned as a way to stitch together attractions such as Millennium Park and the Chicago Riverwalk.</p><p>The Loop Alliance is working with the organization Arts Alliance Illinois and consultancy firm Sound Diplomacy on an economic impact study on the arts, which will be released this summer, and it will announce more arts-related public programming announced at a later date.</p><p>The importance of the arts to Downtown was also the focus of a panel discussion at the meeting, which drew nearly 500 attendees.</p><p>John Collins, executive director of the Goodman Theatre, said the arts are key to the Loop because it attracts viewers from every neighborhood. It’s also an experience more people want in today’s age, he said.</p><p>“People come to the theater and they feel connected [to] people around them. They feel connected to something larger than themselves,” Collins said. “I think acutely, in this moment post-COVID, the demand and the need for experiences that provide that type of connection is stronger than ever.”</p><p>The Loop Alliance also announced it received an $800,000 two-year grant from the Department of Planning and Development to help fill vacant storefronts, through community investment like preparing the empty spaces and supporting small businesses. The number of vacant storefronts on State Street dropped nearly 14% in the fourth quarter of 2025, compared to the previous quarter. More than 40 new restaurants, cafes and retail stores opened or will open soon in the Loop.</p><p>The organization also received a $1.1 million grant to expand its social service outreach program in the Central Business District. The program will launch in the spring.</p><p>Chicago Loop Alliance CEO Michael Edwards said the member-based business organization “continues to thrive.” </p><p>The Loop Alliance in 2025 supported funding for the Chicago Transit Authority, along with the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/real-estate/2025/04/25/office-residential-conversions-apartments-housing-downtown" >LaSalle Corridor Revitalization</a> projects in the Loop. The revitalization <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/real-estate/2024/06/22/lasalle-street-apartments-office-adaptive-reuse-tif-johnson" >projects</a> will create mixed-incoming housing in the Loop by repurposing office buildings along LaSalle Street. Research from commercial real estate firm Cushman & Wakefield shows the city’s office vacancy rate rose steadily throughout 2025, ending the year at 26.9%. That figure has been on an uptick since mid-2020, according to the firm.</p><p>But Onni Group, Shamrock Trading, Zurich and Hireology all signed deals to lease or own office buildings in the Loop. Logistics company Shamrock plans to expand its existing Lombard office to Downtown. Software firm Hireology will move into the upper floors of the Marshall Field building, 24 E. Washington St.</p><p>The organization highlighted the Downtown Islamic Center’s purchase of 213-227 S. State St. to redevelop the historic building into a community space and educational center. Construction also continues on Google’s redevelopment of the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/real-estate/2024/05/06/thompson-center-google-prime-capri-redevelopment-loop-headquarters" >Thompson Center</a>, which is set to open early 2027.</p><p>The Loop Alliance took a moment to thank Edwards for his leadership, as Friday's event would be his last annual meeting. Edwards is stepping down on March 31 as the CEO, after 13 years at its helm. The organization plans to name his successor by April.</p><p>“Your dedication and hard work and unwavering optimism has shaped … the city,” James Turner, past chair and board member of the Chicago Loop Alliance, said. “Thank you for your years of service, your leadership and your friendship.”</p><p><i>Contributing: Amy Yee</i></p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/work/2026/01/12/chicago-loop-alliance-ceo-michael-edwards-step-down" >Chicago Loop Alliance CEO Michael Edwards to step down</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/real-estate/2025/04/25/office-residential-conversions-apartments-housing-downtown" >Offices in the Loop and beyond are being converted to apartments. Can the city do more?</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p></p>
entries.author: Abby Miller

entries.title: Bulls' turnover problems one of many issues facing coach Billy Donovan
entries.summary: <p>Bulls guard Josh Giddey never has been one to point fingers or get caught up in making excuses, so he’s not about to start now.</p><p>Giddey would have every right to do so, given he has watched half the nameplates in the locker room change in the last month and given the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bulls" target="_blank" >Bulls</a>’ 11-game losing streak. In his mind, however, this is the NBA, and pros don’t dwell on what has gone wrong. They try to fix it.</p><p>‘‘Our job is to go out and perform and win games,’’ Giddey said. ‘‘Obviously, we’re not going to keep using the excuse it’s a new team. We’re past that part now. It is frustrating because you build so much continuity with the team you have, and then it gets torn apart within a couple of days.</p><p>‘‘We’ve got to find ways to get out of the hole and figure it out as a group. Nobody is feeling sorry for us. There aren’t asterisks on the stat sheet saying it’s a new team together. It’s on us as players to figure this out.’’</p><p>That’s good thinking, but how do the Bulls do that?</p><p>If Giddey and the rest of the Bulls don’t do a better job of taking care of the ball, then getting to know one another better, making shots and playing better defense won’t really mean much. It starts there, and the ugly numbers back that up.</p><p>In their last five games, the Bulls have committed 99 turnovers (19.8 per game) and have allowed 119 points (23.8 per game) off those turnovers.</p><p>‘‘It’s really, in a lot of ways, the decision-making in the moment,’’ coach Billy Donovan said. ‘‘We’ve just got to try getting better at it. It’s hard because a few of them were just careless turnovers, [such as] the ball was handled too much or trying to do too much with the ball and it’s just not there. But more than anything, it’s the decision-making piece that we’ve got to keep working at and keep showing them to try to get better at.’’</p><p>If there was a training camp to do that or even a few consecutive days of practice, maybe Donovan and his staff could start chipping away at some of the bad habits. But Donovan is fighting another uphill battle, too.</p><p>Not only are several of his key ballhandlers, such as Giddey and Tre Jones, on minutes restrictions, but the Bulls are undermanned in the frontcourt, too. Even if he could get his guards to play with better ball security, they’re playing with teammates such as seldom-used forward Leonard Miller and undersized Guerschon Yabusele.</p><p>This isn’t a winning roster when it’s at full strength, let alone playing with a bunch of<br>G Leaguers and castoffs.</p><p>Donovan never will admit it, but it’s unlikely the Bulls will win games consistently for the rest of this season. Still, that doesn’t mean he can’t do everything possible to try to coach some winning habits into his team.</p><p>That’s why he’s focused so much on second-year guard Rob Dillingham. Since arriving from the Timberwolves in the trade for Ayo Dosunmu, Dillingham has been trying to re-establish himself as a prospect after being selected No. 8 overall in the 2024 draft.</p><p>Donovan remains all-in on helping him in that process.</p><p>‘‘I’ve had talks with Rob about getting him to try to change his mentality,’’ Donovan said. ‘‘He viewed himself as a scoring point guard, which is good, but you also have to be efficient [at] his size. How can he change his mentality of how he needs to start looking at the game?</p><p>‘‘We’re trying to help these guys, as well as going out and win. Can I use this time to try to help them? It may not always lead to wins, but it may help make them better players.’’</p><bsp-list-loadmore class="PageListH" data-module data-hide-authors="true" data-hide-categories="true" entries.author: Joe Cowley

entries.title: What we know about Rev. Jesse Jackson's death and plans to honor his life
entries.summary: <p>The Rev. Jesse Jackson <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/obituaries/2026/02/17/rev-jesse-jackson-civil-rights-leader-rainbow-push-obituary" target="_blank" >“died peacefully”</a> Feb. 17, his family said during a news conference last week. He was 84. </p><p>Jackson is a Chicago icon known for his work as a civil rights leader. "All are welcome" for services scheduled this week, according to his family.</p><h3>When are services?</h3><p>Jackson will lie in repose <b>Thursday </b>and <b>Friday</b>, at Rainbow PUSH's Kenwood headquarters at 930 E. 50th St. The services both days will start at 10 a.m. Doors will close to the public and media at 9 p.m. </p><p>The service dates were adjusted after officials in South Carolina and Washington, D.C., offered to memorialize him there as well, so his remains will be traveling between Sunday and March 5.</p><p>On <b>March 2</b>, a full day of recognition will take place at and near the South Carolina state capitol, according to communications from Rainbow PUSH. </p><p>Jackson will lie in repose at the Statehouse in Columbia before private, public and church services take place throughout the day. A formal service will take place at 10 a.m. at 1100 Gervais St., Columbia, S.C., 29208. Later that afternoon, a tribute service will be held at Brookland Baptist Church from 4 p.m. to 6 p.m at 1066 Sunset Blvd. Pastor Charles B. Jackson, Sr. will be officiating. </p><p>On <b>March 4</b>, a formal service will take place in Washington, D.C. Details are forthcoming. </p><p>Omega Psi Phi Fraternity Incorporated, a Divine Nine fraternity that Jackson was part of, will hold a celebration of life service at 5 p.m. on March 5 at Rainbow PUSH. Grand officers, district officers and various members of the fraternity will be in attendance, said a district representative. </p><p>A "People's Celebration" in Chicago will be held at 10 a.m. <b>March 6</b>, at House of Hope, 752 E. 114th St. Doors open at 9 a.m. Additional parking will be available at nearby businesses. Shuttles will then transport people to the venue.</p><p>Janet Pickett, the general manager at House of Hope, said they are planning for more than 9,000 people to attend. (The venue seats 9,600.) There is no word yet on who will be leading the services, she said. Ushers and personnel for the event will be staffed by House of Hope and Rainbow PUSH. </p><p>Private homegoing services are scheduled for 10 a.m. <b>March 7</b>, at Rainbow PUSH. Doors open at 8 a.m., with limited capacity. </p><p>Relatives of Jackson said that "all are welcome," regardless of political party.</p><p>"Do not bring your politics, out of respect to Rev. Jesse Jackson and the life that he lived, to these homegoing services. They come respectful and come to say thank you," Jesse Jackson Jr. said during a media event in front of the Jackson family home. "But these homegoing services are welcome to all — Democrat, Republican, liberal and conservative, right wing, left wing, because his life is broad enough to cover the full spectrum of what it means to be an American."</p><p>The family will livestream all services at JesseJacksonLegacy.com. </p><h3>How are Chicagoans paying their respects at the services?</h3><p>Thousands gathered at <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago/2026/02/26/rev-jesse-jackson-lying-in-repose-rainbow-push-chicago" >Rainbow PUSH on Thursday</a> to pay their respects to Jackson. The family procession arrived after 8 a.m. As the morning wore on, hundreds were lined up to show their gratitude for Jackson and be a part of a historical moment. </p><p>Mayor Brandon Johnson and Rev. Al Sharpton were in attendance on Thursday to pay their respects.</p><p>"We spent a lifetime together," said Sharpton outside the Rainbow PUSH headquarters. "He raised a generation of us and he never gave up, even when he was sick." </p><p>Friday's crowds included <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago/2026/02/27/jesse-jacksons-death-inspires-young-people-more-present-community" >several Black youth that were inspired by Jackson</a> to be more present in their community. </p><p>Among them was Nadiyah Spikener, 24, who said Jackson's death could be a catalyst for young people to learn more about their history. </p><p>"This may be a moment to realize that maybe we need to do more for ourselves, and do more for our community like he has, and just start somewhere," she said. </p><h3>What hotels are recommended for those traveling to Chicago for the events?</h3><p>Those traveling to Chicago to attend services are encouraged to stay at the Hyatt Regency McCormick Place Chicago at 2233 S. Martin Luther King Drive, according to the family's website. Rooms at the hotel have been reserved within a hotel block, with limited availability. </p><h3>Where can people park?</h3><p>For those hoping to attend the Jackson lying in state events, street parking is available at Rainbow PUSH on South Drexel Boulevard, East 49th Street, East Hyde Park Boulevard and East 49th Street. </p><p>For the People's Celebration, parking will be available at House of Hope's parking lot on 113th Street. </p><h3>What security measures will be in place?</h3><p>At each event, security checks and magnetometers will be in place. The family's website asks that individuals limit items brought to smooth the process. Weapons, signs and any items that could disrupt services are prohibited</p><p>For more information on the scheduled services visit <a class="Link" href="https://www.jessejacksonlegacy.com/" target="_blank" >jessejacksonlegacy.com</a>. </p><h3>Where will the Rev. Jesse Jackson be buried?</h3><p>Jackson will be buried at <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/curious-city/2025/06/04/prejudice-follows-us-to-the-grave-the-segregated-past-of-chicago-cemeteries#:~:text=Mayor%20Harold%20Washington%20is%20buried,bring%20it%20to%20an%20end." target="_blank" >Oak Woods Cemetery</a>, the largest cemetery on the South Side, in Greater Grand Crossing. Former Chicago Mayor Harold Washington, journalist and civil rights activist Ida B. Wells and Olympic athlete Jesse Owens are among those buried there.</p><h3>How did he die?</h3><p>While his family has not given an official cause of death nor said where he died, Jackson had been declining in health for a decade before his death. In 2015,<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2017/11/17/18375473/rev-jesse-jackson-announces-parkinson-s-diagnosis" > Jackson was initially diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease</a>, but he revealed last April that he actually had progressive supranuclear palsy.</p><h3>How is the political world reacting to his death?</h3><p>Political figures from across the country have weighed in to pay their respects and honor his legacy. </p><p>In a joint statement, former President Barack Obama and former first lady Michelle Obama wrote: "Michelle and I will always be grateful for Jesse's lifetime of service, and the friendship our families share. We stood on his shoulders. We send our deepest condolences to the Jackson family and everyone in Chicago and beyond who knew and loved him." </p><p>President Donald Trump also extended his sympathies to Jackson's family in a statement posted to Truth Social last week. </p><p>"I knew him well, long before becoming President," he said. "He was very gregarious — Someone who truly loved people! Despite the fact that I am falsely and consistently called a Racist by the Scoundrels and Lunatics on the Radical Left, Democrats ALL, it was always my pleasure to help Jesse along the way."</p><p>Chicago leaders, including Mayor Brandon Johnson and Gov. JB Pritzker, also shared their condolences. </p><p>"In honor of Rev. Jackson's service, and as our city mourns, the Chicago flag will lower to half-staff," Mayor Johnson wrote in a statement. </p><p>Pritzker also ordered all flags across the state to fly at half-mast to honor him in a statement posted on social media.</p><p>"He broke down barriers, inspired generations, and kept hope alive. Our state, nation, and world are better due to his years of service," Pritzker said.</p><h3>How are Chicagoans reacting to his death?</h3><p>Across the city, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2026/02/17/jesse-jackson-chicago-remembers" >Chicago residents mourned Jackson’s death</a> and urged that his legacy continue. </p><p>Martin Travis, a congregant of Apostolic Church of God in Woodlawn, said in his youth, his parents brought him to demonstrations organized by Operation Breadbasket, a movement Jackson led. </p><p>Now, 64, Travis remembers Jackson as "instrumental in fighting for justice and freedom for all people."</p><p>Chloe Gould, 41, a Bronzeville resident, said that his death hit "like you lost a family member." </p><p>In the wake of his death, she said she worries about the future of civil rights activism, as other activists and leaders have not stepped in to fill his shoes. </p><p>"Who is gonna be the civil rights activist now?" she asked. </p>
entries.author: Nicole Jeanine Johnson

entries.title: Babette Peyton, disabled Army veteran who competed in archery tournaments, dies at
entries.summary: <p></p><p></p><p></p><p>Babette Peyton, a disabled Army veteran, was an inspirational figure to thousands of Chicagoans.</p><p>Sitting in her wheelchair, Ms. Peyton shot a bow and arrow using one arm and her mouth.</p><p>She bit into a mouth tab attached to the bow string, extended her right arm holding the bow, aimed, and unclenched her jaw — flinging her arrow at the target.</p><p>Ms. Peyton, who was partially paralyzed following a training accident in the Army and a stroke later in life, won more than 150 medals competing in archery tournaments around the country and the world.</p><p>And she did it with a indefatigable and contagious happiness.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/581ba28/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1516x851+0+599/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F85%2Fe8%2Fdd190158430ca600f759b6bf1e8b%2F3976906868860852571.JPG data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Ms. Peyton’s message to everyone was always “Do not give up,” her family said.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Provided</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>"She's a person you don't forget because she brings so much joy," said Derek Daniels, who worked with Ms. Peyton as director of Adaptive Sports and Fitness at Shirley Ryan Ability Lab.</p><p>Ms. Peyton died Feb. 11 from natural causes. She was 73.</p><p>In 2009, unsure about her future after suffering a stroke and being confined to a wheelchair, Ms. Peyton attended a military paralympic sports camp in Newport, Rhode Island, where she first tried archery.</p><p>Instructor Kevin Stone showed her how to use her teeth to hold the draw string. Her first two arrows missed the target. She fired four more without noticing much where they landed, until she was told that two of them were bullseyes.</p><p>"At first she sat out, didn't want to participate because it looked to difficult, but I was like 'Nobody sits out at my clinic,'" recalled Stone, a military paralympic athlete and mentor who showed MS. Peyton how to shoot.</p><p>"She told me later that I changed her life," Stone said.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-670000" name="image-670000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/972d412/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2100x1179+0+111/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F23%2F0e%2F575027234243aab43cee2b7971e0%2Fdudek-1-1.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/76c8279/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2100x1179+0+111/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F23%2F0e%2F575027234243aab43cee2b7971e0%2Fdudek-1-1.jpg width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/c140648/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2100x1179+0+111/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F23%2F0e%2F575027234243aab43cee2b7971e0%2Fdudek-1-1.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="dudek-1 (1).jpg" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/c140648/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2100x1179+0+111/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F23%2F0e%2F575027234243aab43cee2b7971e0%2Fdudek-1-1.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/ba96964/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2100x1179+0+111/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F23%2F0e%2F575027234243aab43cee2b7971e0%2Fdudek-1-1.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/c140648/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2100x1179+0+111/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F23%2F0e%2F575027234243aab43cee2b7971e0%2Fdudek-1-1.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Ms. Peyton first tried archery in 2009 at a a military paralympic sports camp in Newport, Rhode Island. She went on to win more than 150 medals competing in tournaments around the world. </p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Provided</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>"One thing I remember emphatically about her was how happy she was and how she had an infectious laugh . . . she really, really did, and she was just a joy to be around always," Stone said.</p><p>Ms. Peyton took public transportation and practiced archery at various ranges in Chicago, including at the Croc Center, and was a regular participant at the Valor Games Midwest, a competition hosted by the Chicago Park District for veterans and service members with disabilities.</p><p>She was also a disabilities advocate who was recognizable by elected officials from all over the Chicago area for her heart and her persuasive powers, recalled Ald. David Moore (17th).</p><p>"She'd come to constituent night to give me my orders in terms of making things more accessible in the ward, and then she'd say, before I could even reply, 'And, David, I love you, and there's nothing you can do about it.' And it shut me right up and all I could say was 'I'll get on it,'" Moore said.</p><p>She was also part of a group of veterans who were the driving force behind the creation of the South Side Memorial Day Parade, Moore said.</p><p>Ms. Peyton was <a class="Link" href="https://www.pbs.org/video/chicago-portrait-babette-peyton-78cdgu/" target="_blank" >featured on WTTW’s “Chicago Tonight” in 2020</a> that opened with footage of Ms. Peyton rolling up in her wheelchair to a community garden in Gresham to feed some roosters, which ran to her as she sang: "Thank you, God. I want to tell you that I love you. I want to tell you that I'm thinking of you. Every minute, every hour, every second of the day. How you doing? I love you! Come on!"</p><p>Ms. Peyton was born Aug 15, 1952, to Arthur Peyton Jr., an Air Force veteran who later worked as a mail carrier, and Rosette Caldwell Peyton, a special education teacher.</p><p>She grew up in South Shore and graduated from South Shore High School before joining the Army in 1973.</p><p>Stationed in West Germany, Ms. Peyton worked at hospital when she was court-martialed in 1975 for refusing to remove cornrows from her hair, a case that was covered in the media.</p><p>The case was ultimately dismissed because it was determined that the order to remove the cornrows had been improperly issued, according to a United Press International story published in 1975.</p><p>"She was very outspoken and stood up for anything she thought wasn't right, especially all types of discrimination," said her niece, Kathy Chaney, a former Sun-Times editor.</p><p>Ms. Peyton suffered a spinal injury in 1976 that was the result of a friendly fire incident during a training exercise in her last year in the Army, she told the Sun-Times in a story published in 2020.</p><p>She was honorably discharged and later attended the University of Maryland before earning a Master of Arts in education from Northwestern University, her family said.</p><p>She also was an entrepreneur who started the Peyton Elevator Company with her brother Renard Peyton, which installed elevators in Chicago, including at several South Side churches.</p><p>"She was the first Black female elevator contractor in the city," Chaney said.</p><p>Her message to everyone was always "Do not give up," her family said.</p><p>She is survived by her siblings Celeste Randolph and Renard Peyton, as well as 11 nephews and nieces.</p>
entries.author: Mitch Dudek

entries.title: Bears offensive line coach Dan Roushar: Left tackle answer ‘to be determined’
entries.summary: <p>INDIANAPOLIS — The <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >Bears</a> didn't expect to be addressing left tackle anytime soon after drafting Ozzy Trapilo in the second round last year, but <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2026/01/11/bears-left-tackle-ozzy-trapilo-linebacker-t-j-edwards-out-for-season-after-injuries-in-packers-game" >his knee injury in the playoffs</a> changed that drastically.</p><p>General manager Ryan Poles has said Trapilo will miss at least most of the upcoming season, which puts the position high on their list of priorities this offseason. The Bears certainly don’t want a repeat of last season, when they started with Braxton Jones, benched him for Theo Benedet, then benched Benedet for Trapilo.</p><p>Offensive line coach Dan Roushar said on an episode of five-time Pro Bowl left tackle Terron Armstead’s podcast, The Set, that it’s “to be determined” whether the team has an in-house solution.</p><p>“I know what the left tackle position looks like in this league,” Roushar said in an episode released this week. “[Armstead is] the standard. That’s a rare player that comes along. But somebody has to play that position similar to that. It’s a faceless, nameless guy right now.</p><p>“Is that player in the building? There’s guys that have traits, but not consistent enough. ... So that’s to be determined.”</p><p>Premium positions like left tackle usually require teams to use premium resources, which Roushar acknowledged. He said finding a good enough player there requires “draft capital, or an asset we currently don’t have,” and added, “It’s most likely either through free agency or it’s here in the building.”</p><p>For now, not knowing who the Bears could get in free agency next month or in the draft in April, when they’re picking No. 25 in the first round, Roushar said, “We’re going to work with the guys we’ve got and we’re going to make it better.”</p><p>Jones, a fifth-round pick in 2022 who started 44 games over four seasons, is a pending free agent but unlikely to command big offers. Spotrac projected his market value as a two-year, $9.5 million contract.</p><p>Benedet, who was undrafted out of Canada in 2024, is an exclusive-rights free agent who can be brought back cheaply. Amegadjie, a 2024 third-round pick who has one career start, has two seasons left on his rookie contract.</p><p></p><p></p><p></p><bsp-list-loadmore class="PageListH" data-module
